Was advice provided to the Deputy Prime Minister before he made his remarks? If so, what was that advice?

—Senator Bolkus, I haven't seen the full text of what it is that you allege Mr Fischer said. But it is not unusual for you to raise aspects of what someone said and then have to wait for me to go back and check entirely what Mr Fischer said. Can I, however, just give you a generalised response. There are conventions and proprieties, some people might call them, about comments with respect to judges, but there has never been the suggestion that judgments should not be subject to criticism or to scrutiny. I would expect that any judgment that touched on native title would be scrutinised by the federal government and you would expect that, too. If you want to allege that Mr Fischer said something you think is inappropriate, it is a matter you should take up with the Attorney.

—Can I suggest to the minister that she would be in a better position to answer questions if she read her briefs, rather than filling out Christmas cards during question time. I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that Mr Fischer has described one High Court decision as awful, has accused the justices of the High Court of unacceptable judicial activism and has now attacked the Federal Court, how does your government expect Australians to maintain confidence in the federal judicial system if the Deputy Prime Minister reserves the capacity to belt the judicial umpires when he does not agree with them?

—I think Senator Bolkus lacks some basic understanding about the institutions that we rely on very heavily and, in particular, about what the independence of the judiciary means. It is no surprise. He was the shadow justice minister. He has been moved out of that for a whole variety of reasons, not the least of which was the touting of Federal Court documents around the place off the record. But he should understand—everyone on this side clearly understands—that the independence of the judiciary does not mean freedom from total scrutiny. It has never meant that. This is a free country. People are entitled to look at judgments of a court and they are entitled to say whether they agree with them and think they are workable or not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Can the minister confirm that the mining company ERA wishes to withdraw from mining uranium at Jabiluka? Is it the case that ERA has already initiated discussions with the government and that the government has refused to countenance the idea or to provide any assistance for such a withdrawal?
—That is news to me.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Will the minister undertake to find out whether such discussions have taken place with your department or any other department? Will you advise the Senate of the outcome of those discussions? If you do not know anything about the ERA withdrawal, have you responded to questions raised by the tourism industry about the ramifications of the Jabiluka mine for tourism in the Northern Territory? What studies have been done on the impacts of having Kakadu placed on the world heritage in danger list? Will tourist operators such as World Expeditions be compensated for losses arising out of Kakadu losing its world heritage status?

—Kakadu is not on the world heritage in danger list. I showed last week that the Wilderness Society confused the retention ponds with the billabongs up there which it refers to. It is also interesting that IUCN, which is the chief adviser to the World Heritage Committee, has also done so in its major publication.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. I asked the minister some direct questions. I did not ask about calendars or anything else. I ask you to direct the minister to answer the question.
—There are a number of parts to the question. Senator Hill may deal with them if he has time to in the time available.

—I only mentioned it because IUCN is the independent adviser to the World Heritage Committee. It has a lovely photo of the retention dam on page 44 of its guidelines. It comes with the name of Jim Forsell, who has been the principal adviser, as a matter of interest. So I do not think it is going to worry the tourism industry. Even IUCN thinks it is okay. As a matter of interest, as I understand it, the Ranger mine is the second most highly visited area of the region. Yellow Waters is the first area, and Ranger uranium mine is the second. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the minister to Minister Ruddock's attack on Federal Court judges, accusing them of undermining the government's refugee policy. Does the minister agree with Minister Ruddock that judges had ignored High Court guidelines on the handling of refugee appeals? Is it the case, as Minister Ruddock asserts, that judges do not have the breadth of experience or knowledge of the impact of their decisions in this area? If so, what action does the minister propose to take? If not, does she propose to correct the minister's attack?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. Obviously what we are on about here is some sort of suggestion that the government has been attacking the judiciary. I just wish that members opposite had such respect for the High Court and for the Federal Court when Justice Callinan was appointed. Senator Bolkus might like to have thought about that before he went on a wholesale attempt to undermine Justice Callinan. Senator McKiernan is, generally speaking, a much more reasonable and informed person than Senator Bolkus. The minister would ask that you consider what the High Court has said about how the courts should approach the judicial review of administrative decisions. In one case—that of Wu Shan Lan—four High Court judges in a joint statement said this:

answer.para: The reasons of an administrative decision maker are meant to inform and not to be scrutinised upon overzealous judicial review by seeking to discern whether some inadequacy may be gleaned from the way in which the reasons are expressed. In the present context, any court reviewing a decision upon refugee status must beware of turning a review of the reasons of the decision maker upon proper principles into a reconsideration of the merits of the decision.
The other High Court judge in that case said:

It is erroneous for judges to adopt a narrow approach, combing through the words of the decision maker with a fine appellate toothcomb, against the prospect that a verbal slip will be found warranting the inference of an error of law.
He went on to say:

The reviewing judge must be careful to avoid turning an examination of the reasons of a decision maker into a review of the merits of the decision where the judge is limited to the usual grounds of judicial review.

There are other examples I could quote. What the minister is highlighting is that he shares those views of the High Court on how the judicial review of migration and refugee cases ought to be conducted. Turning to the matter of parliament's intention, in the minister's view it is clear that the current judicial review scheme in the migration legislation was intended to exclude some grounds of judicial review. That legislation spells out in detail the requirements for a visa and the procedures to be followed by the departmental decision makers, and gives extensive merits review of visa decisions.

The Federal Court has taken a different view in numerous cases and has imported backgrounds of review, which this parliament has excluded. The minister has appealed the first of the cases referred to the High Court and is currently awaiting the judgment of that court. That puts in a more sensible context than the odd phrase here or there what the minister is trying to do. I think you can see that the High Court agrees with what the minister says. That is the minister's contention.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. A very important component of my question was about the minister's assertion that judges do not have the breadth of experience and knowledge of the impact of decisions. I asked the minister whether she agrees with that and, if so, what she is going to do about it. I also ask: by not naming the judges has not Minister Ruddock attacked all the Federal Court judges, not just the few?

—If you reflect on the answer, you will see that Mr Ruddock is saying parliament has quite specifically sought to take some areas out of judicial review for a variety of reasons, presumably on the basis that parliament is a better place and the minister and the decision makers are better equipped to make those decisions. On that basis, it follows that Mr Ruddock's remarks would be aimed at that aspect of a decision that parliament has in fact made. There are some decisions that are best made by ministers and other decision makers; that is, they are not judicial decisions. I am sure you understand the difference between a judicial decision and a decision on its merits.

answer.para: As to the minister not selecting any particular judge, he is entitled to make his remarks in general. He might feel that it is more respectful to make his remarks in general instead of doing what Senator Bolkus tried to do to High Court Justice Callinan. He completely undermined that judge by nominating him and sending staff up to Brisbane to see what he could get to attack the judge. There is a bit more respect for the High Court on this side of the chamber than there has ever been on that side. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. Is the minister aware of current deliberations within the WA Planning Commission with respect to a development proposal for the Creery Wetlands near Mandurah, south of Perth. Can he advise whether his department has been consulted on this latest development proposal and what action he proposes to take, particularly in light of the area's proximity to the Ramsar listed Peel-Yalgorup wetlands system and the inevitability that the proposed development will impact on the Ramsar listed areas? Finally, what is the status of the proposed memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth, state and local government authorities and the developer?
—We have already saved the wetlands.

—We have all saved them from time to time, Senator. Yes, they are important wetlands in Western Australia and there has been concern for some time that development proposals do not damage the conservation values, particularly the values of the Ramsar listed Peel-Harvey Estuary. That has, as Senator Faulkner interjected, been a concern of successive Commonwealth governments. We do not easily have a head of power under which to act, as the honourable senator would be aware. For the Commonwealth to intervene on Ramsar issues at the moment is a somewhat tortuous path. If Senator Margetts will join with us in implementing our environmental reform legislation that we have before the parliament, she can have greater confidence in relation to these matters in the future.

answer.para: Apart from a rather awkward procedure that has never been tested, the Commonwealth's process has largely been persuasive in relation to this particular matter. When the issue of development has from time to time lifted its head, successive Commonwealth governments have, as I said, become involved in an effort to protect the values of the wetlands. We of course are the state party to the Ramsar convention and have that responsibility, even though the Commonwealth government did not see fit to implement those obligations specifically under domestic legislation.

It was my objective some time ago to complete a memorandum that I thought would give greater protection, but we were unsuc cessful in that, and then the issue of further development seemed to go onto the backburner. There is a suggestion that it is now back before planning authorities. We will therefore continue to act in the way that we have in the past to persuade the Western Australian government to ensure that these values are properly protected.

talk.start.para: —I wish I could be assured that the minister has done everything in his power but I am not sure that I can be. Does the minister have any plans to incorporate the entire Creery Wetlands under the existing Ramsar listing for the Peel-Yalgorup system, of which the Creery area is an integral part? Given that the development is adjacent to a Ramsar listed wetland and would be included as part of that listing if it were not for its private ownership, has the Commonwealth government been a party to the deed of agreement?

—Extending the wetlands is not necessarily the answer. The issue is whether the development can be compatible with the adjoining conservation values, and that is the question that we have been addressing. I should give Senator Campbell some credit because he too has taken a great interest in this matter over many years, from the conservation perspective and also from the jobs and economic perspective. We believe in a balanced outcome in these difficult matters.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Civil Weddings

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney-General. What did the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, mean when he said on the Meet the Press program yesterday that the proposal of the Association of Civil Marriage Celebrants to take legal action against the government for the unfair impact of the GST was `politically correct poppycock'? Was the Deputy Prime Minister serious in suggesting that civil marriage celebrants should pay a 20 per cent surcharge to cover the cost of cleaning up after their ceremonies and a further 20 per cent to subsidise the cost of maintaining the premises of religious celebrants? Or was he just being his usual idiosyncratic self?

—Madam President, I am not sure that it is appropriate to ask me what Mr Fischer meant when he said something. I would have thought in respect of the first phase that it was pretty obvious what he meant. I think it is self-explanatory. In relation to the other matters, Senator, it may come as a surprise to you but I do not watch every current affairs program on Sunday morning. I will have a look at the program and I will ask Mr Fischer if there is anything that he would like to add to enlighten you as to his remarks, and if he has some information that he wants to give me to pass on to you I will make sure that I do it by the end of the week.

—Madam President, perhaps the minister can deal with this supplementary question. What does the government propose to do to remove the obvious inequity of imposing a 10 per cent tax on civil marriage ceremonies while exempting religious ceremonies?

—The whole concept of a new tax system was taken to the last election—which, incidentally, we happened to win, Senator O'Brien, if you had not caught on. All of the detail of these matters will be very adequately debated when the bills come in. I am sure you can see, Senator, and that you are just pretending that you cannot see, the difference between exemptions for religious services and commercial services provided by a wide range of other people. There is a clear difference between those. There have always been exemptions for religious services in one way or another, and the fact that that is maintained does not seem any surprise to me. The civil celebrants are working on a commercial basis and would therefore expect to be included.

—My question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Will the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to attract new investment and to create more jobs in Australian industry? What assistance will the government provide for the development of the new pulp and paper mill at Tumut in New South Wales? What benefits will the project bring to the region and to Australia more generally?

—I thank Senator Brownhill for his question. Unlike the opposition, this government understands that, if you want to create jobs, you need sustainable economic growth and, if you want sustainable economic growth, you must have investment. Twelve months ago, we released a very major statement on investment called `Investing for growth', which identified investment as the critical element in creating economic growth and, therefore, creating jobs. In that statement and as part of our strategy in relation to investment, we announced the establishment of Invest Australia, which is our new investment promotion and facilitation agency.

answer.para: We also said at that time—in a very major decision—that, in special and limited circumstances, we would consider providing investment incentives for particular projects where there was clear economic benefit to Australia and where that economic benefit might not accrue to Australia unless the government took positive action to assist the investment. We also announced at that time the appointment of Bob Mansfield as the strategic investment coordinator.

Yesterday I was pleased to announce the first initiative under that program, through the work of Mr Mansfield, and that was the government's decision to provide $40 million in order to enable the establishment of a pulp and paper mini-mill at Tumut in New South Wales. This is a tremendous project. It will provide around 1,000 new jobs in the region around Tumut. It is the first mini-mill of its kind in the whole world. The initial investment will be some $450 million, and there will be further investment down the track. It will produce 300,000 tonnes a year of unbleached kraft pulp and paper for industrial and packaging uses. It will, most importantly, replace imports of about 30,000 tonnes, and there will be about 100,000 tonnes for export.

The government's assistance will be provided in several ways. The majority will come from existing programs—the Roads of National Importance program, the Infrastructure Borrowing Tax Offsets Scheme and the Regional Assistance Program. We will be providing an additional $15 million in the form of a cash grant, and I emphasise that all assistance provided will be treated as income for tax purposes.

Our record in this initiative contrasts markedly with our opponents'. This is the first mill established in nearly two decades. The last mill built in Australia was built under the previous coalition government. There is a record of failure under Labor's period, most notably and disastrously, of course, the fiasco over the Wesley Vale pulp mill—a $1 billion investment lost to the state of Tasmania by your ridiculous inaction and infighting. It was an absolute disaster.

The mini-mill for Tumut, which will proceed under our government, is environmentally friendly. It will be constructed using state-of-the-art technologies and based on the kraft pulping process, which minimises water use through a high level of water recycling. There is no bleaching involved in the process at all. It will use only plantation softwood timber and it will recycle up to 80,000 tonnes of waste paper from New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory. It will I think very significantly result in an additional 30,000 hectares of softwood plantation being planted. So on every score this is a very major initiative. The project is proceeding only because the federal government has made the decision to provide $40 million worth of investment incentives. We welcome this decision.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Has the minister received the letter written by the Judicial Conference of Australia stating that the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge on the incomes of state, territory and some Federal Court judges as well as magistrates breaches the constitution? Has the minister's attention been drawn to the statement by the conference's secretary, Professor Stephen Parker, that the surcharge attacked three centuries of legal tradition that had protected judicial independence from government interference? On what basis can the minister assert, as he did through a spokesperson, that he is satisfied that the law is constitutional and will survive the challenge in the High Court? Did the government receive legal advice to this effect when the legislation was originally drafted?

—Again we have a question relating to the superannuation surcharge. I have not formally sought a ruling, but I have noted here before that elements of the Labor Party are very opposed to the superannuation surcharge—not all the Labor Party, it has to be said, but elements of the Labor Party. Of course, members of parliament and people in the Senate are subject to the surcharge like other high income earners. I just wonder whether we should get a ruling on whether the senator—in standing up and asking a question on the surcharge, which is a critical question—should declare an interest in relation to this.
—Oh!

—It is a very important point. The surcharge is an important equity measure which forms part of the government's policy on superannuation. I might say that, at one stage, it formed part of the Labor Party's policy on superannuation. When it got to the Senate, under Senator Sherry's guidance the Labor Party backflipped. After the bill was passed, the Labor Party backflipped again and the surcharge became part of the Labor Party's policy. So there are two backflips there, Madam President.
—Senator Kemp, I would draw your attention to the question that was put to you.

—Thank you, Madam President. I am drawing some important background to this question. As far as we are concerned, the surcharge should apply in an equitable fashion to high income earners whether they happen to be politicians, people in the Senate or judges. As I said, it is a principle of equity and it is one which the government supports.

answer.para: During the debate on the superannuation surcharge, there were various issues which were raised and debates about whether it was constitutional. In the course of those debates, the government sought advice and, as far as the government is concerned, we are satisfied that the law is constitutional. I understand that other issues have been raised from the conference on the weekend. I will check whether I have received a letter specifically on this matter. I think some of my colleagues have. The important point here is that the surcharge is a matter of equity.

talk.start.para: —It's a new tax!

—Senator Sherry, we know you are vigorously opposed to the surcharge. Unless you can tell me the Labor Party has once again changed its policy on this surcharge—has the Labor Party changed its policy on the surcharge?
—Order! Senator Kemp!

—As I was pointing out, the Labor Party blackflipped once on the surcharge. It has backflipped again. In the course of the election it further backflipped. I would be very interested to see when the senator asks a supplementary question whether we are seeing another change in tack for the Labor Party on the superannuation surcharge.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that difficulties with the implementation of the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge have forced the government to extend the financial assessment date—originally August this year—not once but twice to 15 October this year and now to 15 February next year? Aren't these just further examples of why this legally flawed, ill-conceived, administrative nightmare should not have been proceeded with last year?

—That is an extraordinary statement. Don't you know that it was Labor Party policy? This is quite extraordinary. The senator himself may well have already received an assessment for the superannuation surcharge. This senator is asking us to overturn the superannuation surcharge which each year he presumably will have to pay—unless he has got other particular deductions—and be liable for. I am astonished that a Labor Party senator has stood up in this chamber and attempted to overturn the superannuation surcharge, which I understood was Labor Party policy. I regard it as quite an extraordinary question. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I refer also to the front page of today's Australian in which the immigration minister, Mr Ruddock, attacks Federal Court judges for undermining the government's strict refugee policy. How do these comments match with the fact that, of the 979 decisions of the Refugee Review Tribunal which were appealed to the Federal Court over the last four years, only 21, or two per cent, have been successfully overturned and of these any could then be appealed to the High Court? Are the minister's comments not so much a legitimate complaint about judges succumbing to their personal biases but rather another case of cheap populism by the government, trying to look tough on migrants and bash some judges? Given the fact that any error in judgment by the Refugee Review Tribunal may result in the torture or death on an asylum seeker, isn't the government risking having the blood of at least some asylum seekers on its hands by pursuing its current proposal to limit judicial review of immigration rulings even further?

—I thank the senator for his question. There are a few things I would like to add to the answer that I gave to Senator McKiernan's question. I do not know if you were here for that. If you were not, I refer you to the Hansard . I will repeat something I said last week: the voice of dissent is the bell of freedom. Courts are independent but they are not free from scrutiny or criticism. That has never been the cornerstone of the independence of the judiciary. The minister has expressed a view. He is entitled to express that view; you are entitled to disagree with it. That is what a free democratic system is all about. It does not assist the development of such a system—if you endorse such a system—if every time you disagree with someone you refer to them as a cheap populist. You can be excused for that because you obviously do not know Minister Ruddock very well. But anyone who did know him would know that that is a ludicrous proposition for you to put.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister respond to the reported remarks of former Chief Justice Sir Gerard Brennan that, without judicial review, government power may be abused with impunity and that government or the bureaucracy could refuse to obey the law or observe the rules? How can the government's plan to further restrict judicial review not impact negatively on the many genuine applicants who are simply legitimately pursuing their legal rights and not abusing the system?

—I will refer the senator's supplementary question to Mr Ruddock and see if there is anything he wants to add. The only thing I wish to add is: don't imagine for one minute that everything that happens is always going to be reviewed by a court or a judge and that providing that review in every circumstance is always going to be an appropriate path to follow. I will refer your question to Mr Ruddock. If he has got anything to add over and above that which is already on the public record, I am sure he will.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Does the minister agree with the Kennett government's submission to the Senate inquiry into the private health insurance rebate proposal that fund members on more than $50,000 a year should have to buy full, rather than discounted, hospital insurance before they qualify for the handout and that the rebate should be paid only for hospital insurance, not extras? Isn't Mr Kennett correct in claiming that offering the rebate for extras like dental cover will do little to relieve the pressure on public hospitals? Minister, why should we subsidise your dental care while pensioners cannot afford urgent dental treatment because you closed down the only scheme that supported them?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans for the question. I have learnt with Senator Evans to doubt the question before I answer it.
—Oh, what rubbish!
—Rubbish, somebody said on the other side. On 25 March this year Senator Evans said to me:

answer.para: Today you said you did not know. Were you lying then or are you lying now?

He did not retract that. I checked the Hansard at that time. I had said that they played their politics roughly, as they had done for the last couple of years, and that they had done it with the previous government, which was nothing new. He accused me of lying then and he did not retract, so I seize this opportunity to point out that anybody who hears that sort of question should question the question. He obviously has an agenda that he wants to run. I suggest that he check the veracity of his questions before he asks them.

Jeffrey Kennett is an outstanding Premier of this country. Senator Collins is holding up a news article. The other thing I have learned, Senator Collins, is to question anything I read in the press. One of the columnists in Brisbane, a well-known political correspondent, once said, `Many times with the printed media you can believe only two things: the price and the date, and sometimes they get the date wrong.'

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many conversations in the chamber. Senator Herron, I draw your attention to the question that was asked of you.

—Thank you, Madam President. Premier Kennett is, like many people, knowledgeable on many affairs. But I am afraid that knowledge of health care in relation to this particular debate is not his long suit. He has missed the fact that, where people choose to take out ancillary cover, that is their right. They have the right to choose ancillary cover just as they have the right to take out front-end deductibles. That is part of the system.

answer.para: It is obvious that Australians value the Medicare system and the quality of care it offers to the whole community. The government has introduced legislation so that the 30 per cent rebate of health insurance premiums can be provided to all Australians who want private health cover. This will take pressure off public hospitals. It will make them more accessible. It will get people off waiting lists. Premier Kennett has supported the rebate and encouraged the Senate to pass the legislation that will introduce the 30 per cent rebate from 1 January 1989.

talk.start.para: —What year? Is it 1989 or 1999?
—My apologies, 1999. Thank you, Senator Schacht. It was a typo.
—You haven't got a clue what you're talking about.
—Senator Faulkner, stop shouting!

—The rebate funding is provided by the Commonwealth in addition to the support it provides for public hospitals under the new health care agreements. These agreements have been negotiated and agreed with all of the state premiers, including Mr Kennett, and all of their health ministers.

answer.para: Our commitment to Medicare is clear. In 1998-99, about $5.7 billion in current prices will be paid under the agreements. This is a funding increase of 8.8 per cent in real terms for the states and territories over the last year of the Medicare agreements, 1997-98. At the end of the agreements in 2002-03, the total funding in real terms for the states and territories will be 16.5 per cent greater than the 1997-98 rebate. So there is quite a dramatic increase under the Medicare rebate system under the agreements that have been agreed to by all the state premiers, including Premier Kennett.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. First of all, I am sorry if the minister has harboured some offence since March this year. It is the first time he has raised it with me. I am surprised it took him so long if he was so mortally offended. But, Minister, the question went to the heart of your government's priorities. You are proposing to spend $200 million subsidising dental cover for the rich, all those people who have been brought into the rebate scheme, while you closed down the only scheme that allowed dental care for pensioners and other poor Australians to get urgent dental treatment. I ask: what are your government's priorities? Why will you not provide dental health for the poor who cannot afford care while you will subsidise your own dental care?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am pleased that Senator Evans brought that up, because he did not understand his own government policy at the time. When in government, the Labor Party introduced the dental care subsidy and said it was for a fixed period to alleviate waiting lists at that time and it had a finite ending. Senator Evans was not aware it had a finite ending under the Labor Party government, of which he was a part at the time. So it is absurd for him to bring this up. He did not understand his own policy.

answer.para: As I have said previously, the reality is that people are given the freedom of choice whether to insure for ancillary cover or front-end deductibles. We are trying to make up the ravages that the Labor Party brought into private health insurance in the 13 years that they had it, when they intentionally tried to devastate the private hospital system of this country. They tried to destroy it. We are trying to restore it, and we will restore it if this legislation is passed.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hogg today, relating to superannuation.

I rise to take note, yet again, of the debacle that is the government's superannuation surcharge as outlined by Senator Kemp. I invite Senator Kemp to stay and join the debate to defend it, yet again. As always, the surcharge has been brought further and further into disrepute. We have seen over the last 18 months the government trying to pretend that it is not a tax. We all know it is a tax. We all know that the government has got itself into such a horrendous position on this tax simply because it was caught out when it promised no new taxes. What was its solution? It stood up and said, `It is not a tax; it is a surcharge.'

The government promised the Australian electorate before the 1996 election there would be no new taxes. Yet in its first budget, nearly 2½ years ago, it broke that promise with a new $500 million tax. It found that the only way it could try to pretend to the broader community that it had not broken that promise was to call it a surcharge. Senator Sherry humiliated Senator Kemp over many months on this issue, the pretence that this was not a tax. Today we are seeing, yet again, more evidence that the surcharge, or tax as it is officially known on the books of this parliament, is in actual fact unconstitutional. You have got yourself into such a mess on it that you have allowed it to become fundamentally flawed. You come before this chamber and ask, `What is the Labor Party's position?'

talk.start.para: —I'm going to listen to this.
—The Labor Party's position is absolutely clear, Senator Kemp. It is absolutely clear.
—Address the chair please, Senator Conroy.
—The Labor Party's position is that it supports this measure on an equity basis.
—Oh, you support it.

—But this government has made such a mess of this measure—such a total and utter debacle—that we were in a position where we opposed the mechanism used to collect. It is that simple, Senator Kemp. You have made such a mess of the collection mechanism simply to avoid having to admit that it is a tax.
—Would you address the chair, Senator Conroy.
—What you have done is you have forced every single—
—Senator Conroy, please address the chair.

—Every single superannuant in this country has to pay for the collection of this tax. It is paying through the nose not just in lower returns but also in higher admin fees. This government stands condemned by the industry, by ordinary Australians and by their superannuation funds because you have made such a mess of it.

speech.para: It has been calculated that, to raise $100 of surcharge tax revenue, it is costing each super fund $54. That is a fact. The super funds have been forced to put such a ridiculous amount of administration into this bill that it is costing $54 to collect $100. This is the most inefficient collection method. It is almost as if the government sat down and said, `How can we so completely stuff this up that it is going to cost almost half of what we are going to raise for this tax?' And it designed this mechanism, Senator Kemp, through you, Madam Deputy President. The reason the Labor Party voted against this mechanism is that it is such an inefficient and inequitable measure. We have seen it questioned during the committee hearings as unconstitutional. There was more evidence over the weekend that it is unconstitutional. The government got caught pulling a fast one, pulling the wool over the eyes of ordinary Australians.

We have seen in this measure lower returns. Each and every Australian with a super fund is getting a lower return when they retire because of this government. We have seen funds having to take money and put it into the cash side of their investment account. Cash is very reliable, but it has a very low return. That is what is happening. We have seen massive increases in costs. We have seen delayed assessments. Many of the people whom this measure was designed to hit still have not received an assessment from this government. Perhaps Senator Kemp can tell us why. That was the very question that was asked.

talk.start.para: —Two and a half years later.

—Two and a half years later, and we still have not seen assessments for the very people this tax is designed to collect money from. They have been unable to collect the tax file numbers for hundreds and thousands of ordinary Australians. (Time expired)

—I was somewhat provoked to stay behind in taking note of answers to listen to Senator Conroy. I have made the mistake before in tuning into Senator Conroy: I learnt nothing. I regret to say that my initial impression has been confirmed again by Senator Conroy's effort, except for a very important statement that Senator Conroy made. I must say that I raised the question at question time whether the Labor Party supported the surcharge or not. We know that Senator Sherry was the most vigorous opponent of the surcharge. No self-interest there, Senator Sherry.
—None at all.

—Some will ask whether this is to Senator Sherry's credit or whether, to take another view of Senator Sherry, this decision is one of extreme self-interest. The Labor Party supported the surcharge in the lower house. But when it came up here, under the guidance of Senator Sherry, the Labor Party attempted in every possible way to defeat the surcharge. Not one senator declared self-interest in this. Not one senator indicated that, if the surcharge was defeated, this would mean massive savings to virtually all senators in this chamber. Not one of them declared an interest. I was interested to hear Senator Conroy's comments as to whether the Labor Party had backflipped again. You will notice that I went through a sequence of the backflip.
—Did you declare interest on the savings rebate?
—Senator Sherry, you have had your time.
—Senator Kemp, would you please address the chair.

—You have had your chance. You are on the record, Senator Sherry. Senator Conroy said that the Labor Party supports this measure as an equity measure. That is a very important statement. Apparently we are seeing the Labor Party's continuing support for the surcharge.
—But not a measure that's going to make the poor people pay.

—Well, you are not poor, Senator Conroy, and presumably you are liable for the surcharge. Then he said, `However, we are unhappy with the way the collection mechanism works.' We waited during the debate in the Senate, because this was the argument that Senator Sherry ran. He was unhappy with the collection mechanism.
—So is everyone else.
—We put up an alternative.
—You didn't. You actually withdrew all your proposed amendments.
—Order! Senator Conroy and Senator Sherry will come to order and cease interjecting. Senator Kemp, you will address the chair and ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I hope that you will show some kind of control over your colleagues. The fact of the matter is that while I was debating the measure I was subjected to constant harassment from that side.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Carr!
—Madam Deputy President, are you planning to take any control over your colleagues or not?
—Senator Kemp, I do not require that sort of comment and assistance.
—I shall be tuning in, Madam Deputy President, very carefully to the remainder of this debate.
—You might learn something.
—Order! Those on my left!

—What we learnt was that the Labor Party then attempted to propose an alternative collection mechanism. Then they went and did some research and found that it did not work; they found that it was highly complex and led to major problems, not the least for small business. So Senator Sherry dropped it. Senator Sherry, if my memory serves me correctly, never moved those amendments.

question.para: I shall be listening very carefully to hear what is the alternative collection mechanism that the Labor Party proposes for the superannuation surcharge because, as I have noted, it does have a huge self-interest in this area. As a politician, as a higher income earner liable for the superannuation surcharge, the Labor Party has a huge—

talk.start.para: —Why are you making everybody up there pay to collect my tax?
—Order! Senator Conroy, please desist from interjecting.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I think your instructions from the chair have been constantly ignored by your colleagues. You might like to exert some clearer authority, if I may suggest to you.
—No, you may not.
—So here we have the Labor Party with no alternative collection mechanism—that is the truth—none whatsoever.

—You had a couple of years to work out an alternative collection mechanism, and you could never do it. Either the Labor Party is as incompetent in this area as it is in every other area, or it was just utterly bone lazy. Take your pick: it is one of those two. Or perhaps there is an alternative—that the Labor Party looked closely at it and decided that, all things considered, this was the appropriate mechanism.(Time expired)

—Senator Kemp, in an attempt to distract himself and the government from the inadequacies of the particular problems of the so-called superannuation surcharge, challenged senators to declare an interest. We certainly did not see Senator Kemp, for example, declare an interest when—
—The savings rebate.

—the so-called savings rebate was introduced—$450 to every senator automatically. We did not see Senator Kemp following that line. And I will be interested to see Senator Kemp declare an interest when this government's so-called tax reform GST legislation comes into this Senate which reduces income tax for everyone in this place by far more than the fair share that we should receive. But that is not the issue.

speech.para: The issue relates to the so-called superannuation surcharge—in effect, a tax. This was the government's major tax reform announced in 1996: an additional tax of $½ billion. But Treasurer Costello did not call it a tax. He said to himself, I am sure, `Well, we went to the election in 1996 saying "No increases in existing taxes, no new taxes". So we've got to call the new $½ billion tax on superannuation something new; we'll call it a surcharge.' That was the fundamental beginning of this government's problem in collecting this $½ billion new tax.

This new tax on superannuation does not just apply to higher income earners who earn more than $72,000; it also applies to many people who in certain circumstances earn less than $72,000. If they fail to provide a tax file number, persons who earn less than $72,000 are required to pay the full 15 per cent of the tax—the full 15 per cent. So it is not equitable in that sense.

But there are a number of other fundamental flaws with this new tax. This new tax was budgeted to collect almost $½ billion in 1997-98. What did the government end up collecting? It collected $347 million. That means there was a $133 million shortfall. We have asked Senator Kemp why they had a shortfall of $133 million. No answer; waffle, but no answer. What happened to that $133 million that was budgeted to be collected in the first year? It is not an insignificant amount of money. It is about a third of the estimated amount of revenue that this new tax was going to raise—and it has not materialised.

What did it cost to collect this new tax, the $347 million in revenue? In the first year, industry estimates—not Labor Party estimates but those of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia—are that, to collect $347 million, it cost $160 million; $160 million to collect $347 million. So, for every dollar raised in revenue in the first year, it cost almost 50c; almost 50c to raise a dollar in revenue from the new super tax. I might say that cost does not include the $20 million to $30 million it has cost the tax office. So we have $347 million in revenue, $133 million dollars short, and it cost $160 million. It is Australia's most expensive tax.

talk.start.para: —In the world.

—In the world, my Senate colleague interjects. It is one of the most expensive taxes in the world to collect; certainly in Australian history we have never seen anything like this. And this was this government's, Mr Costello's, major tax reform of its first term in office. This was announced in the budget of 1996. Two and a half years later, the assessment notices are still going out—2½ years later. So on any efficiency arguments, equity arguments, this tax is a monumental failure—and highlighted today, of course, by the approach of the judges. It is not just Labor—it is judges, fund managers, trustees, lawyers, accountants, economists. You are hard pressed to find anyone who supports the collection mechanism of this new tax. It is grossly inefficient. If this is a prelude to the GST, God help the Australian population when you have a tax that costs almost 50 cents in the dollar to raise. (Time expired)

—I also rise to join this debate and pick up a couple of points made by Senator Sherry. Senator Sherry is somewhat specialised in this area of tax surcharge, unlike his colleague frontbencher Senator Conroy. Senator Sherry is the expert. Whenever Senator Conroy concludes a speech during a debate that he has started on such financial matters, he walks out of the chamber, leaving the debate to Senator Sherry. I do not know why Senator Conroy does not leave it entirely to Senator Sherry.

speech.para: Senator Sherry, I want to pick up a couple of points that you made about the administration costs of collecting this surcharge. I think you said that $347 million was raised in the first year and some $160 million was needed to raise that. That was the administration cost. As you know and must concede, the first year is always more. It gets less as the years go on. There is an establishment cost to raise these sorts of surcharges and taxes—there is no doubt about that, Senator Sherry. Of course it is a somewhat more complex system compared to other taxes, so you must concede that means testing is not always the best way to go when it comes to raising special surcharges and taxes. So you would then perhaps agree that the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance should not be means tested.

The second point you made was that there is a shortfall in the government's estimate in raising a certain amount of the surcharge—we may have estimated for some $500 million and we got $347 million. Do not worry about our shortfall. We balanced our budget. Overall, this was part of the grand plan of our first budget. As tough as it was, there was a method behind the government's policies, such as this surcharge. Some of them were tough to do, but we carried them out and we are now reaping the benefits, Senator Sherry. So do not start telling us we have not raised enough revenue. What we have done is to balance our budget. We have brought our budget into surplus, and every sector of the economy—every department—has contributed to that. We do not need gratuitous economic advice, least of all from you.

There is an inherent contradiction in the debate today. For example, the opposition is saying that the people who are going to have to pay the surcharge after the $70,000 point where the means test starts to cut in are poor people. Yet, with the 30 per cent health rebate system, they say the $70,000 income earners are rich people. So, Senator Sherry, there is an inherent contradiction in your argument.

The second contradiction is that the House of Representatives Labor supported it but the Senate Labor did not support it. What went wrong in between the two houses? Who did the heavy lobbying on this? In actual fact, it was an ideological debate. By the time it got to the Senate, it was an ideological debate for the Labor Party and the ideology is pretty easy to understand: they have to pay the surcharge on their parliamentary pensions. That is the ideology behind this.

Senator Conroy said that if government had to sit down and work out how to stuff up a tax system, this is the way to do it. Well, if the government had to stuff up the tax system, they would keep the existing tax system. That is the best way to stuff up the tax system we have, and that is exactly what you want to do: keep the existing tax system. You want to keep the existing wholesale sales tax with all its inequities and absurdities where, for example, frozen yoghurt does not get wholesale sales tax but soft yoghurt, which looks like ice-cream, does get wholesale sales tax. That is how you stuff up the tax system: keep the existing tax system. If you want to untangle the mess we have before us, support the government's tax reform system. If you want to untangle the budgetary mess we have, then support the surcharge tax on superannuation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I asked a very simple question of the minister today, and he was not able to respond. We know, of course, that the minister is responsible for waffle answers, but for the first time today, consistent with his indisposition of last week, we got a jelly belly answer.
—Jelly belly?
—Order! Please, let's not deteriorate the language any further.

—I thought that was a fairly apt description of the answer I got, because it did not address the question that was asked of the minister. The question was about the problem with the judges—where the judges have now said that the super tax is illegal. That was the question to the minister. The minister did not answer it. The fact is that the judges are saying, quite loudly and clearly—reported—that the super tax is illegal. The government cannot face up to it.

speech.para: It is not a matter of my self-interest or anyone else's self-interest, Senator McGauran. It is purely and simply a fact that the government are yet to address the whole issue of the constitutionality of the change that they brought in. They were repeatedly told that it was unconstitutional, that it was unworkable and that it was an unfair tax for some people—but they ignored that completely. The minister ignored that at his own peril. There was a meeting of judges, who said that the tax is illegal. In today's Age it was reported:
If the litigation goes ahead, the Government will be in the extraordinary position of being possibly the first in Australian history to have its laws challenged by its judiciary.
That is what the government have set up: a challenge by its own judiciary. The statement, through Professor Stephen Parker, further said:
Unless the legislation is repealed, we think that the matter must be decided by the High Court immediately and not become drawn out.

As my colleagues said, from the outset this particular surcharge—this particular tax—has been a complete debacle. It has been ill-conceived and it has done nothing to assist the superannuation industry and those people who rightfully receive superannuation as part of their retirement package. Forget about the issue of what happens in this place, because there is no doubt on our side that the people in this place are liable to pay the taxes that are owed by them. That is not the issue. At issue here is the constitutionality of the law as seen by judges.

The second issue that I raised in my question was the fact that the collection of this tax by the government has turned into a complete debacle. As one of my colleagues alluded to earlier, it has the highest compliance cost in the world for the collection of a tax and it has placed a great impost on funds and fund members. It will ultimately reduce the benefit that is returned to fund members. I have even heard cited that one fund paid some $40,000 to have the reporting charges—

talk.start.para: —Must be a union fund, John.

—No, it was not. But, in spite of that, no members of the fund were actually subject to the surcharge. A fund paid some $40,000 to have the surchargeable amount reported when, in effect, there was nothing to be paid at all. Who bore the cost of that? The fund and the fund members. What we have here is not an issue of equity; we have an issue of inequity for those people who, not subject to the charge at all, had to pay it and get a reduced benefit for themselves.

speech.para: This issue shows nothing more than the fact that the government lobbed on to something that was no good. They stuck with it. It is not a matter of if you are on a good thing stick to it. They should have got rid of it. The minister has done nothing to convince the public or anyone in this place that it is a fair charge. The superannuation funds have repeatedly opposed this charge from its instigation and, as I understand it, will continue to do so. The judges do nothing more than support that contention. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What a spectacle we have here today—the Labor Party talking about economic management! Fancy economic management being the subject of taking note of answers that were given by the government in question time today. We are talking about the most incompetent economic managers that this country has seen for a long time. I am quite sure that Senator Hogg, who was the most recent speaker, is one of those who has suffered and will suffer for a long time because of the legacy of the Labor Party's economic management of this country. He can raise small issues as often as he likes—he can raise issues of constitutionality of law and all the other issues he might wish to—but nothing will ever deflect from the incompetent management of the Labor Party over 13 years they were in government.

speech.para: I am sorry that Senator Sherry has gone because he said in his little contribution that this not only applies to people on incomes over $72,000 a year but also applies to people who are earning less. He failed to say that this does not need to apply to anybody who earns under $72,000. If people cannot keep their affairs in order and will not give a tax file number, it is no different from the legislation you people introduced when it came to savings accounts in banks. If you do not give your tax file number to a bank, then the tax on any interest earned on your savings account will be paid at a rate of 48c in the dollar.

What is the difference between the attitude we have taken to superannuation and the attitude your government took to the savings of Australians, whether they have savings accounts in banks or in other areas which pay interest? They have to give their tax file number in order that the tax will not be taken out at the top rate. It is exactly the same with the superannuation surcharge. Senator Sherry ought to be very careful that he does not mislead the chamber because there is no need for anybody earning under $72,000 a year to pay the top rate, in exactly the same manner that there is no need for anybody who deposits money in a bank account and earns interest to pay the top rate.

He calls it an iniquitous tax. Let me tell you that there is nothing more iniquitous than a high income earner being able to claim 48 cents in the dollar from their contribution to superannuation and someone who pays 20 cents in the dollar being able to claim only 20 cents in the dollar. That is iniquitous and that is why the superannuation surcharge was introduced. It was introduced so that high income earners do not get a distinct advantage over low income earners. Did we hear that from Senator Conroy or Senator Sherry? Not on your life. The last thing they wanted to do was highlight the fact that, as high income earners, they could, if they wanted to, get a far greater rebate on contributions than someone who is on 20 cents in the dollar.

Between 1983 and 1993, in the period of the Labor government, there were 83 major changes to superannuation legislation. So don't let them over there talk about confusing the public about the continual changes to superannuation, which makes it more unattractive to those people in the community who might wish to take it out. Let them look at their own record. Their own record was one of confusing the public year after year and changing the rules as they went along.

Who will ever forget the then Labor government's attitude to their own workers who used to be able to contribute $3,000 a year to their own private funds in order to enhance the savings of Australia, in order to enhance their own retirement income. What did the then Labor government do? It took away the right of workers to claim a tax deduction for up to $3,000 of their own contributions. Don't you talk about looking after the workers, because in this one stroke you caused more trouble and more harm to workers in Australia, especially those older workers who had not been in superannuation schemes for that long, who were trying to build up, over a very short period, their retirement benefit.

You, the Labor Party, took away the right of workers earning low incomes or middle incomes to contribute to their own retirement and claim a tax deduction for it. You ought to think carefully about your own record over those 13 years of government. The issues you have raised today are minimal compared with the blunders you made during that time in making changes to superannuation on a regular basis. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Auditor-General's Act 1997, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 18 of 1998-99—Performance Audit—Accounting for Aid—The Management of Funding to Non-Government Organisations: Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID).

speech.para: Leave granted.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

para.inline: Report on Matters not disposed of at the end of the 38th Parliament

speech.para: The References Committee met on 30 November and considered references not disposed of at the end of the 38th Parliament and resolved to recommend to the Senate that—
1. The following inquiries of the 38th Parliament be re-adopted:
Whether a new reactor should be built to replace the High Flux Australian Reactor at Lucas Heights on that site or on some other site in Australia, with a reporting date of 18 February 1999;
Operation of the Australian Taxation Office, with a reporting date of 30 June 1999.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Korea and Malaysia which took place in July of this year, and I want to make a few short comments in regard to the report. On reading the report again this morning, I recalled the difficulties we had with the two new airports in the region. I suffered more than the rest of my colleagues on that delegation, my luggage going missing for some four days on the way through Kuala Lumpur into Seoul.
—Is that where you got that shirt?

—As a matter of fact, Senator Campbell, that is exactly right. The tie was bought in a different place, and I also got the blazer in Seoul. I was unfortunately travelling in casual gear and on the first few days of the delegation I did stand out somewhat until I was able to get some different clothes. We made mention in the report of the fact that in the one day we actually went through both of the new airports that had been opened in the region. We suffered greatly because of that with huge delays. Nonetheless, the airports now seem to be working and they are a credit to those people who conceived them and built them.

speech.para: I want to pay special attention at the very beginning to the leadership of the delegation leader, Harry Jenkins, the member for Scullin in the other place. Mr Jenkins did a wonderful job in holding the delegation together. We were quite a diverse group with diverse interests. He held the delegation together exceptionally well and, indeed, impressed the people we met in both countries. He was ably assisted by the deputy leader of the delegation, Mr Bruce Reid, who retired at the last election. Bruce was also a real asset to have on the delegation, assisting at every stage when there were any difficulties. Gillian Gould has to be commended for her efforts in keeping the delegation on stream and up to date with developments and meeting our commitments.

It was a difficult time for the delegation to visit both countries. As the Senate would know, both countries have been very severely impacted by the economic crisis that has hit the region and have suffered very badly. Unfortunately, the people who are suffering most are those at the bottom of the socioeconomic ladder. That is something that had an impact on the delegation when we visited. Of course, much has happened since the period in which the delegation visit took place. Some five months have elapsed, and a general election in Australia has occurred as well. In the report, the delegation has sought to stick to what was happening at the time that we visited.

It was a difficult time for us to visit, and that was apparent in the visits that were organised for us. The visit to Korea was better organised than was the visit to Malaysia. Whilst the visit to Malaysia was productive, it could have been much better for us. We only got to meet with one minister in Malaysia, and that was only after the delegation expressed concerns at the briefing with the High Commissioner on the first morning of the visit. We were grateful for that meeting with the minister, but the visit could have been much better. The Malaysians themselves appeared more preoccupied with their own internal difficulties than they were with the visiting parliamentary delegation, and I think our program, to a certain extent, reflected that. But I think we were looking with biased eyes and comparing it with what occurred in Korea, a very close and, indeed, very important trading partner with Australia. The people in Korea were very pleased to see us and were very grateful for Australia's interventions in their economic difficulties. Our support for the IMF package was also appreciated, and that was expressed in comments to us.

In Malaysia, there seemed to be a preoccupation with the happenings of the One Nation party in Australia. We were reminded that a previous delegation which visited Kuala Lumpur some 18 months ago had told the Malaysians that One Nation was an aberration and would not be around very long. We were reminded that since that time the Queensland state elections had been held and, indeed, the One Nation party was actually stronger than it had been previously. So that was a difficulty that we had to come to grips with in Malaysia. In many respects it would have been nicer to have gone to Malaysia this week than to visit at that particular point in time.

Honourable senators would know that the area where I was born, only 10 miles from the border that divides Northern Ireland from Ireland, has experienced conflict for the last 300 to 400 years. I have not personally experienced it, but it has been going on for quite a considerable period of time. Even all of that did not prepare me for the visit that the delegation made to Panmunjom, the border area that divides North Korea and South Korea. I was not prepared for the tension that was very evident in that particular part of the world. There are some welcome signs on the horizon in North Korea and South Korea that there might possibly be hope for some form of peace in the near future.

In Korea I was most impressed by our two meetings with the trade union bodies in Seoul: the Federation of Korean Trade Unions and the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions. They are two separate organisations that, it would appear, spent quite a considerable period of time opposing each other over the years. At this present moment in time, they are combining to protect the workers of Korea who are suffering particularly badly because of the economic crisis.

Korean unemployment has increased from 452,000, that is 2.1 per cent, in October 1997 to over 1.5 million, seven per cent of the work force, in June of this year. It is predicted to reach two million, over 10 per cent, by the end of 1998. There are some particular difficulties for working people in Korea. These include the fact that it is mainly small business enterprises that are going bankrupt and they are the ones that are laying off the most workers. There is a very low level of trade unionism, only 1.6 million out of a labour force of some 22 million, and for those who do lose their jobs, redundancy provisions are very poor. One can perhaps understand why there is such a low level of trade unionism. We were told that between 1988 and 1997 more than 2,500 unionists were imprisoned for more than six months, and 10,000 for less than six months. So it is not easy being a trade unionist in Korea. The visit to the Samsung factory outside Seoul was very impressive and shows what has been achieved by that company in that area of the world.

One very disturbing statistic for me as a Western Australian visiting Korea was the decline in Korean imports of iron ore from Western Australia. Iron ore imports to Korea suffered, in the first quarter of this year, a decline of 44.5 percentage points, which will obviously have an impact not only on my constituents back in the Pilbara region in Western Australia but also on the overall Australian economy.

I commend this report to the parliament. It is perhaps somewhat dated, but that is not necessarily the fault of the delegation. Upon our return to Australia we were preoccupied with the federal election and getting that out of way and then had to meet again to agree on the content of the report. There will be some useful references in the report for others to build upon the relations that we have both with South Korea and with Malaysia.

Perhaps the greatest effort has to be put into our relationship with Malaysia. There are very great strains on the relationship between Australia and Malaysia. They were expressed to us in regard to One Nation, but also expressed to us was the disappointment that had continued to be felt because the Australian Prime Minister had not personally visited. The effluxion of time has meant that particular difficulty does not remain. The Prime Minister has been up there for the ASEAN conference. Nonetheless, I think there is great suspicion about what Australia is about in the region.

The country obviously is in some degree of turmoil. When we were there Mr Anwar was the Deputy Prime Minister. As we speak now, some five months later, Mr Anwar is on trial and is being held in prison. That causes some constraints. Australia, as a country that defends human rights, ought to be making stronger comments. The delegation refrained from making comments on the human rights situation. We felt that it would not have been appropriate at that point in time to have included those criticisms, one could say, in this report. With those final words, I commend the report to the Senate.
