One does get a little irritated by the claim made, for instance, by the Victorian Farmers Federation pastoral group that they were operating out of an economic analysis and everybody else who supported the freeze option was operating out of a political agenda. It is easy to make that claim.

Within the church we often have the same kind of debate where people on one side will say, `We believe the Bible, but you don't. That is the problem.' It is almost the same kind of debate: `We have the truth and you are operating out of a political agenda.' I simply do not accept that. We operate from different agendas and different positions, but let us not claim for our position absolute truth and for every other position absolute error. That is just not how it operates in the real world.

Perhaps one final piece of information is that I discussed this whole issue with Senator Andrew Murray—a Democrat colleague of mine who has an economics degree, who is a businessman and who understands markets—very fully and he certainly supported the direction taken by this legislation. That just puts on the record the fact that the Democrats, and I am sure the government, are not simply operating out of a political agenda. We have made use of the various economic analyses which have been given to us. We certainly understand the politics which are operating, but we are seeking to do the very best for the industry that we can. While it was possible to promote and support a chill option some months ago—although there are a number of people who tell me that that would not have worked either—it is no longer possible to do so. For that reason, the Democrats will not support the Labor amendments.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the Labor amendments before the chair, it ought to be understood that the difference essentially between the opposition and the government-Democrat arrangement is that the opposition is supporting the view of the majority of the industry—as reflected by the Wool Council, the New South Wales Farmers Association, the Victorian Farmers Federation, the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association and the United Graziers of Queensland—based on the economic analysis by ABARE of the effect of the freeze on the industry and on the stockpile. We are of the view that the majority industry position which existed prior to the government's decision on the freeze is still able to be implemented. Indeed, that is the evidence which the committee received last Friday week from Wool International. As I understand it, the Wool Council is of the view that, if Wool International believes that is still an option, it ought to be supported.

speech.para: When you get down to it, the difference between our position and that of the government and the Democrats is that we say approximately 15,000 bales per quarter ought to be able to be sold to meet the interest costs and the operating costs of Wool International pending its privatisation or demutualisation. That seems to me to hardly be a heretical departure from the position the government takes, but it would require a departure. It would also require of the Democrats a departure from the position they have been taking for some months now.

What effect would that have? Let me refer you to the evidence which we took from Mr Laird of the Australian Wool Growers Association about what has been happening in the market over recent weeks. At page 20 of the committee Hansard, I asked Mr Laird the following:
Senator O'BRIEN—Right. So we have taken a minimum of 90,000 bales from the stockpile out of the market and they have been replaced with 75,000 bales in the last fortnight from the private stockpile.
Mr Laird—Yes. But what you have to realise is that the private stockpile is held commercially. It is held by us—
Senator O'BRIEN—I understand that.
Mr Laird—and it is a commercial decision as to when we want to sell it.

The opposition's point in relation to the freeze, which I clearly outlined in my speech in the second reading debate, is that the freeze imposes a penalty on Wool International unit holders. The information we have is that, when coupled with the costs of privatisation—which the evidence tells us will be somewhere between $4 million and $5 million—the unit holders of Wool International will pay somewhere between $25 million and $30 million for the privilege of having their asset frozen and demutualised so that holders of private stock can take advantage of the market.

We are saying that, if there is any view in the industry which has some degree of common support, it is that there should be enough of the stockpile sold merely to pay the interest costs on the debt, the storage costs and the administrative costs of Wool International. Let us forget for a moment about the costs of the demutualisation and privatisation, because that is dealt with in another amendment. We are saying that those unit holders, quite a number of whom have provided their units as security for loans, not be disadvantaged by a freeze which is preventing the sale of at least 90,000 bales per quarter—the evidence we have is that is being replaced substantially out of the private stockpile—but that about 15,000 bales of their assets be sold to meet their costs so they are not $20 million, $25 million or $30 million out of pocket at the end of the process. The evidence before the committee tells us that the cost of the freeze together with the cost of privatisation will range somewhere between $25 million and $30 million.

So that is the difference between the positions. We are saying that this is an achievable target compared with the amount of wool from the private stockpile which is going onto the market now. According to evidence—evidence that was not contradicted—given before the committee by an organisation that advocates the freeze, 15,000 bales or thereabouts are going onto the market compared to 75,000 bales from the private stockpile. We believe that Wool International unit holders who do not hold or do not seek to sell private stockpile wool ought not be disadvantaged in the interests of those private stockpile holders who do seek to sell their wool, who do seek to take advantage of the market conditions which are created by the freeze on the wool stockpile. Frankly, if the intent of the legislation is to restrict the amount of wool going onto the market and thereby somehow affect the price, isn't it just as possible that all you will do is create the opportunity—in fact, that is what the evidence is showing—for private stockpile wool to fill that gap?

We were also given incontrovertible evidence that the price, although it initially rose, has come down again. We had evidence that a total freeze is not going to have the substantial effect on the price that some people had hoped. We had evidence that, if we sell from the stockpile only the amount necessary to meet those costs, at least there will be an equitable position which holders of Wool International units can be satisfied with—that is, that to all intents and purposes there is a freeze with the exception of the amount of wool necessary to cover their costs.

I put it to the Senate that if this bill is passed without the amendments we propose there will be winners and losers. The winners will be those people who hold private wool stockpile and who seek to sell it. The losers will be those people who hold Wool International units and who choose not to sell any private stockpile they might hold.

This issue is complex. In terms of an outcome for the industry, there is a lot of black and white and grey. The Labor Party have looked at what the majority of the industry want in relation to this bill. The evidence is that they support the chill option and not the freeze option. We have looked at the available economic modelling and decision making on this issue. I must say, Senator Woodley, that what you said in the committee stage of this debate was the first time I had heard you outline the detail of any economic evidence that you have. To this point in time, the impartial, authoritative evidence—if I can put it that way—is supportive not of the freeze but of the chill option. I do not seek to simply put down the source of your economic advice, but I would like to have the opportunity to analyse it more thoroughly.

On the material that was available to the committee, it seems that the only reasonable conclusion we could have come to was that the government did not take the best option when it decided to support the freeze. The government had better advice and chose not to use it. We have the benefit now—and, indeed, the government has the benefit—of accepting the chill option, of accepting the sale of what is essentially a very small part of the wool stockpile and providing equity to those Wool International unit holders.

If the legislation is carried without amendment, then I go back to what I said in my speech at the second reading stage—that is, that there will be a series of unit holders who will be economically disadvantaged by that decision. I would like to hear from the parliamentary secretary as to what the government's view is about that matter and what advice, if any, the government has on the potential liability which might arise from a decision to freeze the stockpile and impose costs on unit holders, having regard to the evidence which Wool International presented to the committee.

talk.start.para: —To take your last comment first, Senator O'Brien, the effect on the unit holders is something that could be discussed when we are dealing with the other amendment. In your amendment, which we are discussing at the moment, we are simply talking about the freeze as compared with the chill, which is what you propose. The government does not support those proposed amendments because they do not deliver all the benefits to the market of a freeze. They would divert demand from the fresh wool market and they would only prolong the uncertainty. As I said in my earlier remarks, we need to move on.

speech.para: Any stockpile sales in the current climate would reduce the opportunity for growers to sell this season's clip. Suspending the stockpile sales, as we provide for in this bill, will allow growers to release some of their wool stocks, whether it is off the sheep or out of the woolshed, and they will be able to realise some much needed cash in the current difficult market circumstances. So I agree with Senator Woodley, and the government will be opposing this amendment.

talk.start.para: —I listened very carefully to what Senator O'Brien was saying. I think he puts a very good case for the chill option, but it is a bit late. I have the Hansard in front of me. Certainly Senator O'Brien gave an accurate account of what was in the Hansard as far as it goes, but he could have gone on and said that I made the point that not only were the 75,000 bales from the private stockpile sold but also—and I don't have the figure—an amount of fresh wool was sold at auction. The effect of that on the industry has been to give a lot of confidence back to the industry.

speech.para: The effect on the unit holders of the stockpile being frozen would be a serious issue if we did not understand that there are a number of private offers on the table. They certainly project a very good result if the total stockpile is sold according to one of those offers. All of the offers that I have seen are well above the current market price, so there will be a profit to the unit holders if the privatised company decides to go ahead and accept one of those offers. If it doesn't, then it will be making a commercial judgment that it can do even better by holding on to the stockpile. But that is a decision for that new company when it is put in place.

So while I think Senator O'Brien presents some pretty good arguments for the position he is putting, I do not think those arguments stand up in the situation we are now faced with, which is to have the freeze in place so that we can put the whole problem to one side and then move ahead to the demutualisation and privatisation. That will be the opportunity for the industry to take control of its own destiny.

talk.start.para: —I rise to respond to the comments just made by Senator Woodley and also by the parliamentary secretary regarding this notion that unless we have a total freeze, which the government is proposing and the Democrats are supporting, then somehow we will not be moving ahead. Senator Woodley just used the words that we have to `move ahead', and that somehow, therefore—I think I am interpreting him correctly—we cannot be revisiting the issue of the chill option. I would be willing to accept that argument if it had been the case that all of the witnesses who came along to the hearing the other day and who made their position very clear as to what their views were just prior to August, when the government made its first announcement, had said: `Look, it doesn't matter what we thought then; we now want the freeze.' That is not what the evidence was.

speech.para: As Senator O'Brien pointed out, the various organisations made it clear that, firstly, they opposed the freeze and, secondly, they supported the chill option but, thirdly, a number of them made it clear—and subsequently we have been made aware—that they still believe that is an option, one that was to be properly considered by the committee. That is why we took evidence on that Friday, the 27th. As far as we were concerned—and I am sure as far as quite a number of those organisations that came along and appeared before us were concerned—the possibility of the chill option was still on the table. That is still the position today.

We have to be careful that we do not confuse the concern that the industry groups have about a complete reversal, that is, going from no freeze to an announcement about a freeze on 4 August, with the intervening period when there was an election and Wool International was, in effect, prohibited from having a freeze because legislation required them to continue to sell down from the stockpile and then subsequent to the election the minister announcing that the government would present legislation forthwith to the parliament to enact the freeze. That has been pretty much the history.

As a result of that uncertainty, organisations were making two things clear to us: firstly, `We do not want chopping and changing, we do not want a complete reversal'; but, secondly, in their view the chill option was still a viable option and one that should be considered. That was made clear by Mr Thirkell-Johnston of the Wool Council. I asked him specifically:
What is the position of the Wool Council now? Is there acceptance—
that is, of the freeze—

simply because Cabinet made the decision and that is it? Or do you feel that the issue should be looked at further and that possibly the freeze should not be enacted or that one of the other options should be considered?
He said:
I think we should still support the chill option but I doubt whether it is possible now.
He wasn't saying, `Don't do it.' He was saying, `We would still support that option,' but that he had doubts about whether it was possible to bring it about.
Further on at page 9 of the Hansard, he said:
I think we are still of the opinion that Wool International should be allowed to keep contact with its customers.

Subsequently, we know that the position of the Wool Council is that it believed the chill option to still be a viable option and one that should be considered. I remind senators again that that is what we were doing on that Friday. There was no point in having the hearing of the Senate select committee unless we considered not only the government's decision for a freeze and how that came about and who supported it and who did not but also what the alternatives were and whether they were still ones that were available to be put into place either in lieu of the freeze or in conjunction with it.

I do not need to quote in detail, but the Victorian Farmers Federation made it clear on page 25 of the Hansard that they still sup ported the chill option. The New South Wales Farmers made it clear and the United Graziers Association of Queensland have made it clear. As we are advised, there is nothing that prevents it from being put into place. So we reject this notion that somehow we are preventing the industry from going forward. Indeed, the chill option only arises on the basis that, firstly, you have a freeze of sales from the stockpile other than for this limited exemption; that is why it is called the chill option. If people were able to listen tonight, they might be wondering what we are talking about with all this freezing and chilling. But we all know what we are talking about. A chill is, in effect, a form of a freeze.

Secondly, it is intended to be put into place to enable the industry to go forward through the privatisation or demutualisation process but in a way which ensures that the ongoing costs and debt servicing costs of Wool International will be met over the next six months or so. As a result of that process, as Senator O'Brien has so eloquently argued, we will not be impacting upon, to their detriment, the equity of those unit holders.

I think it is a lost cause, but I appeal to Senator Woodley to think about it again. We are not trying to stop the industry going forward. We are saying that the industry should go forward and that it should go through the process of demutualisation. Wool International should be privatised. That should be done within the time frame that has been outlined; we have grave doubts about that. We will ask some questions about it shortly. We should do it with the overwhelming support of the bulk of the industry organisations, which is to allow some very limited sales of that stockpile to occur to cover those costs.

talk.start.para: —Although Senator Woodley said in not so many words that there were lies, damned lies and statistics, I suspect that on this occasion we have quotes, quotes and selective quotes. Paragraph 3.25 on page 11 of the committee's report states:

speech.para: Although opposed to the freeze, by the time the Wool Council appeared before the Committee . . . it had accepted that the freeze was going to come into place. According to Mr Thirkell-Johnston ". . . we have gone beyond the position of no return as far as the freeze is concerned."
So there is a variety of views. Again:

The Western Wool Growers, Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia, expressed a similar view . . . `. . . the realities of life are such that the freeze is in place now . . . So the decision to make the freeze is now history. I believe, and our association believes, that it is time to move forward—
`time to move forward' is exactly the phrase that Senator Woodley and I have used—
and deal with the freeze in the best possible way.'

You will always find associations and individuals who disagree, obviously, with the decision that the government has taken. But, for the reasons I have outlined, the government believes that this is the best decision, and that is the way we are going to move.

talk.start.para: —I will bring those quotations up to date. On page 15 of the Hansard , Mr Thirkell-Johnston was asked questions about reconsidering the chill option. At the top of page 13, he said:

speech.para: If you want my personal opinion—
talking about the chill option—
I think it would still be a better way if it were possible, but I doubt whether it is practically possible.
I then said:
We may ask Dr Richardson to take that on notice as well as the other questions.

Having been at all the inquiry's hearings, I can tell you that Dr Richardson did take it on notice. In response to a question on notice, he said that it was feasible. My understanding, from talking to Mr Thirkell-Johnston at that hearing, was that he accepted, if it were possible, that the chill option was the better way to go.

I am not trying to prolong this debate. However, the suggestion is that there was selective quoting or misquoting of the facts. They are the facts. That is the more up-to-date position which Mr Thirkell-Johnston took at the hearing. It is all very well to say `Go forward', but we have said—and I do not think I need repeat it—that the proposal now before the Senate is one that puts the unit holders backward. It does not advance them at all.

talk.start.para: —I put to Senator O'Brien that the question before the Senate now is whether to freeze or not to freeze. Who is playing politics now? The government is playing policy here in the best interests of the wool growing industry of Australia. We have stated our position, and I believe that it is the right one.

—I have to rise because I object strongly to the suggestion that I have selectively quoted from the Hansard in order somehow to use an answer to establish a proposition that was not otherwise evident. I will read out the full quote for the benefit of the parliamentary secretary, who of course did not have the benefit of being at the hearing. This quote is from pages 14 and 15 of the Hansard , which is after the quotations that you referred to, Parliamentary Secretary, that come from the majority report.
—Just as you quoted from the minority report.

—It is a pity; if you just listened, Parliamentary Secretary, you might learn. After asking Mr Thirkell-Johnston as to the position of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, which supports the chill option, Senator O'Brien asked:

speech.para: Is the position of the TFGA that they still support that option?
Mr Thirkell-Johnston —They would still support that. They were the strongest group opposing the freeze in the original argument.

Senator O'Brien —Are you saying that the Wool Council would not support that option and would not support a move to amend the legislation now before the Senate to that effect?—very pertinent to what we are debating now.

Mr Thirkell-Johnston —The point is that we have not discussed whether the legislation could be amended or not. The position that we had taken is that the freeze to all intents and purposes is there. I doubt very much whether you could even amend the legislation. You would have to ask Dr Richardson whether that chill option could now be enacted. I have some doubts whether it could.
Senator O'Brien then asked whether, if Dr Richardson from Wool International was of the view that it could be amended, that would have an effect on the Wool Council's views.
Mr Thirkell-Johnston replied:

I think many of our members would be affected, but not all, by any means. You would have to ask the individual states that question as they come before you. If you want my personal option, I think it would still be a better way if it were possible, but I doubt whether it is practically possible.

Now the whole point is that Mr Thirkell-Johnston's position on behalf of the Wool Council was not that they were saying that they did not want the chill option anymore. Their position was based upon doubts that it could actually be enacted, because they believed that the freeze that had been announced by the government was, to all intents and purposes, in place and that it would even be doubtful the legislation could be amended to change it to a chill option.

The facts of the matter now are that, firstly, that is possible; and, secondly, that the position of the Wool Council has strengthened in recent days and it is now clear from advice that they would have no difficulty with the legislation being amended to enact the chill option rather than the freeze. I believe that needs to be firmly placed on the record, because we are not seeking to quote selectively. This has been a process whereby people's positions have been modified but it is very clear that, once the organisations that have supported the chill option as the best way forward for them have come to the realisation that it is possible to amend this legislation to put that into effect, that is the position that they support in preference to the total freeze, the position of the government and the Democrats.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Democrats amendments Nos 1 and 2 on sheet 1190:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 7, page 4 (lines 21 to 28), omit paragraphs (b) and (c).
(2) Schedule 1, item 7, page 5 (after line 14), after subsection (5), insert:

(5A) Nothing in this Act is to be taken to require Wool International to meet any additional expenses incurred either by Wool International or the Commonwealth in connection with the activities referred to in subsection (1).

I do not want to speak at great length to these amendments. What they are doing is taking up the cry of not just some of the witnesses—against which we put contrary opinions of other witnesses—but the consistent cry of all the witnesses, whether they come from the Australian Wool Growers Association, from Tasmania, from PGA in Western Australia, from Victorian Farmers or New South Wales Farmers. All of them were of the same opinion, and that was that the decision to move towards the freeze and privatisation really is one taken by government. A lot of concern was expressed that, although government believes that it is for the benefit of wool growers, putting all the costs against Wool International would reduce the amount of equity that wool growers would finally be able to access and that was an imposition on Wool International that ought not to be.

I have taken up the concerns of all of the witnesses at the hearing; there was not one who dissented. There was no contrary opinion for one side or the other—all of the witnesses were of one voice on this particular issue. Although I expect I am not going to get support from the government or the opposition on this, I nevertheless put on the record that all the witnesses were on my side on this particular issue.

I could have read you the comments of Mr Thirkell-Johnston from the Wool Council, of Mr Laird from the Australian Wool Growers Association, of the Pastoral Group of the Victorian Farmers Federation or of Mr Wolfenden from the New South Wales Farmers Association—I think he is now the president of the Wool Council as well. All of them made this appeal. It is really to do with section 22ZG. As Mr Wolfenden said, `This amendment'—section 22ZG—`is completely open ended and exposes wool growers to possibly unlimited liability.' He is probably overstating it a bit, but he certainly was supporting the position that I am putting. Without labouring the point, I simply say that the Democrats have moved these amendments on behalf of wool growers and particularly on behalf of Wool International so that the equity of unit holders in Wool International will be preserved during the privatisation process.

talk.start.para: —I indicate on behalf of the opposition that we oppose these Democrat amendments. We, therefore, support the provisions contained in the bill—that is, that the expenses incurred in the demutualisation process should be met out of the moneys of Wool International. We also are of the view that there are specific costs incurred by the Commonwealth that should be borne by the Commonwealth rather than costs that should be met out of Wool International funds. For instance, if the minister decides to engage a consultant to advise him or the government on the process of demutualisation, we would see that those costs would be properly borne by the government, not by the industry.

speech.para: We do not see that the provisions of this bill would have that impact. Further, that is an issue that could be followed up through the estimates process in due course. We believe the principle contained here is sound—that is, as the assets of Wool International are held on behalf of, and owned by, the unit holders, the growers, and ultimately the privatisation process is to their benefit, the necessary costs in bringing about that privatisation for the industry's benefit should be borne out of the funds of Wool International.

Senator Woodley made the statement that he moved his amendments, not for this reason, but with the comfort that all of the organisations that appeared before the committee, every single one of them, support his proposition. That is a—

talk.start.para: —A strong argument.

—I do not think it is a strong argument. In fact, if anything, Senator Woodley, it probably would make you wonder why, because the industry is putting here that the government should pay rather than the industry should pay. It would be a unique organisation that would say, `If there is a choice between the industry paying and the government paying, we think the industry should pay.' Frankly, that is just not going to happen, and we know that. So I do not think we should get carried away with the fact there was unanimous support within the industry for this proposition. Their claim was, as you have identified, for the government to pick up the tab for a privatisation process which they are demanding and which is ultimately to their benefit.

speech.para: I do not think the fact that you are representing the views of all the farmer organisations on this issue really carries that much weight. If we could transfer the discussion for a moment to the private health insurance levy, at the end of the day it is easy to argue that people want the government to pay rather than themselves. But anyway that is a debate we will have somewhere else.

There is a range of issues that we do wish to raise about the process of privatisation and particularly some questions to the parliamentary secretary. We have a great concern that the process will not be finalised within the time period, given the experience that we had within the wheat industry. Despite the assurances that were given to this side of the chamber—and I recall also to the Democrats—that everything would be okay and the time line could be met, it came to pass as we predicted. There were major outstanding issues still to be resolved in that process. There are some issues that still have to be resolved here. There is the issue of taxation liability.

It was said to us in evidence in the committee's hearing that the cost of the privatisation was anticipated to amount to only $2 million to $3 million with a very important proviso that stamp duty was not payable at the time of the transfer. I think I am pretty accurately reflecting the words of the witness at that time. Of course, what would be the position if stamp duty were payable at the time of transfer? Secondly, what does that mean for the ultimate stakeholders, the growers, the unit holders in Wool International, in terms of possible future liability? That is one issue that has to be resolved.

Secondly, we are going to have a very full schedule when the Senate comes back in 1999. Given the government's proposed legislation, it is difficult to see how sufficient opportunity will be given, firstly, to the industry and, secondly, to the parliament to examine the proposed demutualisation of Wool International. We are very apprehensive that either the proposed time frame will not be met and/or there will be an attempt by the government to push the further legislation through the parliament without the scrutiny that it deserves.

I need to place those matters firmly on the record. I cannot claim the same degree of experience in predicting and tipping in this Senate that Senator Woodley was claiming earlier. He does go back a few years more than I do, but I would not mind having a small wager that our predictions will come to pass. With those few remarks at this stage, we support the provisions of the bill and, therefore, will not support the amendments moved by Senator Woodley.

talk.start.para: —I would like to place on record the government's view of the Democrat amendments. The government will not be supporting these amendments. We maintain that the cost of privatisation should be met from Wool International funds simply because Wool International unit holders will be the owners of the net assets and will be the major beneficiaries of the change.

speech.para: I also point out to Senator Forshaw that, in relation to his later remarks in that last speech, I did indicate in my second reading speech that we propose to introduce legislation in the new year to implement the preferred privatisation option. This will, of course, be subject to normal parliamentary scrutiny. That is on the record, and the new private entity will commence operations from 1 July 1999.

talk.start.para: —I just want to make a couple of very quick comments on Senator Forshaw's speech. He is quite right. It is not because the witnesses all supported the proposition I am putting to the Senate tonight that we wanted to move these amendments; it is more to do with the very arguments that Senator Forshaw put—that is, there are costs within the demutualisation process that, quite rightly, should be borne by government. That is quite clear.

speech.para: It surprised me that the Labor Party did not move an amendment along those lines. I would have thought that, if that was their conviction, they would have moved an amendment which would have allowed for the appropriate costs to be borne by the government and the other costs to be borne by Wool International. That would have been a compromise position that the Democrats would have seriously considered, but the Labor Party did not put that.

However, the reason for my raising the whole issue of the witnesses was that that seemed to be the major argument that the Labor Party were using in the previous debate in support of their amendment. So I thought that, if I pointed out to them that all the witnesses were in favour of the amendments I am proposing, they would have embraced it on the same basis because that is what they argued in the previous debate on their amendments, but apparently they are able to change track depending on which amendment it is they are supporting.

I will not prolong the debate. I realise that I am not going to get the support here for my amendments. That is a pity because I do believe that we all are keen to make sure that the growers, or the unit holders of Wool International in this case, really will be able to get a maximum benefit from their equity holdings.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the debate we are having about the cost of privatisation and the question of meeting the timetable proposed for the privatisation or demutualisation, could the parliamentary secretary indicate the cost implications of the timetable not being met? That is, would a time overrun in relation to this process influence the extent of costs to be borne by the industry for the privatisation or demutualisation?

—That is a hypothetical question. At this time there is no thought of an overrun, and the legislation will go in the time line that I have indicated. I welcome your concern, and I look forward to your cooperation in making sure that that time line is adhered to.

—I raise the issue because of the evidence Mr Hutchinson from the Office of Asset Sales gave to the committee on the question of the timetable. He told the committee that the legislation needed to be introduced as early as possible and, after I pointed out to him that the first opportunity would be 15 February, he said:

speech.para: I imagine that we will come under very great pressure to have them available for introduction in that week. Certainly that is the sort of timing we have in mind. It could be a couple of weeks later.
I then said:
If they are a couple of weeks later they might not be introduced till March.
Mr Hutchinson said:
I meant a couple of sitting weeks later.
Then I asked him:
At what time would the legislation need to be in place to allow the timetable that has been set out to be given effect?
He said:

We would need to be certain of the legislation fairly quickly in order that we could be certain of meeting the timetable. Therefore, we could enter into commitments with respect to debt arrangements and the like—all of which have a significant lead time and all of which involve transition from the government guarantee and the like. We do not have a clear date yet in our minds.
Rather than go through it all, Mr Hutchinson later said:
. . . if the legislation was not available by early to mid-May at the latest we would be dealing with a very problematic situation, but it may not be a terminal situation.

The essence of the evidence was that there was a very strict timetable. I am heartened by the parliamentary secretary's comments that the legislation would be subjected to the normal process and scrutiny. However, there must be some doubt that that timetable would be met.

Given that, whilst you may say that the question I ask is hypothetical, we are dealing with an amendment which talks about the imposition of costs upon the industry. To the extent of the timetable of the process, the industry will not control the process yet it may—if my suppositions are correct—face additional costs because of not meeting that timetable. I would not want the government to be saying to the Senate, `Well, it is on your head that that cost is being imposed.' I would have thought that, notwithstanding the provision in the legislation, those are costs which should not be imposed on the industry if it is not their doing that the process is delayed and costs are necessarily incurred.

talk.start.para: —I think I have outlined to Senator O'Brien what the time line is. I think you will also find in Mr Hutchinson's remarks that he saw no reason why the time line should not be met. This bill would be given category T status and would proceed along the time line that I have indicated. There would be normal parliamentary scrutiny, and I look forward to the cooperation of the opposition in getting the next bill into and through the Senate.

—There would be normal cooperation in relation to the legislation. I am asking a specific question which goes to the issue that Senator Woodley raised, although not perhaps in the way that his amendments address it. I put it to you that Mr Hutchinson does envisage the possibility of a time failure in relation to the deadlines that are proposed. I am seeking for the industry some certainty as to the level of costs. We do have evidence that the costs were in the range of $4 million from the Office of Asset Sales, with the expectation that there would be an additional half a million dollars from the department.

speech.para: Then there was the question of stamp duty, which I must say is not resolved with any great clarity because the only information we have from Mr Hutchinson is that `the deal should not attract stamp duty at the time of the demutualisation'. I do not know whether that means that it will attract stamp duty at some other time. It may be that you are not in a position to assist us with that. It was a rather imprecise answer from Mr Hutchinson as to the potential for the imposition of costs after the process as a result of stamp duty. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary can assist us now on that.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator O'Brien is making the hypothesis that this is going to run beyond the time line and that all these difficulties will then arise. This process, and some of the processes that he is talking about, will be part of a new bill which will deal with this whole process of demutualisation. It will be subject to normal parliamentary scrutiny, and that is when we can look at it.
—So, if there is an additional cost overrun, the Senate will be happy for that to be imposed on the industry.

—Your words are `if there is a cost overrun'. This is hypothesis and speculation. We are not dealing with that in this bill. What we are dealing with is the bill as it stands and the two amendments. That is what we are dealing with. We are not going into ifs or hypothesis.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Troeth) read a third time.

debateinfo.title: PAYMENT PROCESSING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Payment Processing Legislation Amendment (Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements) Bill 1998 is a complex bill which, in essence, is designed to introduce three significant changes to the social security system. The bill proposes to, firstly, shift the payment system for pensions and allowances away from the payday based payment of the `pension Thursday' system to fortnightly payment in arrears; secondly, allow for individually chosen paydays for pensions; and, thirdly, reduce from 14 days to seven days the notification period for changes in circumstances which affect entitlements.

speech.para: The opposition supports the first two measures but has very serious concerns with the third proposition. It will oppose the reduced notification period and seek to move amendments to maintain the 14-day notification period. The first measure, the change to the administrative procedure for payment of pensions and family allowances by moving away from the single `pension Thursday' system to fortnightly payments in arrears, is, we think, a constructive proposal. It will bring pensions and family allowances into line with other allowances so that they will generally be paid fortnightly and in arrears. We understand, from the government's explanatory memorandum, that this will produce some savings, and it will mean that pension paydays might be spread throughout the week rather than all being on the same `pension Thursday'. Obviously this will increase flexibility and, hopefully, reduce the administrative problems associated with the more rigid structure that is currently in place.

The second measure provides that pensioners and family allowance recipients can choose their paydays, although new and existing customers will be encouraged to choose days other than the traditional Thursdays. Obviously, this will spread payments throughout the week which, we understand, will reduce processing times and allow for greater flexibility. Because all pensions are now paid on the same day, the lead-up time to process these 2½ million payments is some six days. When a person notifies Centrelink of a change in circumstances resulting in a decrease in entitlement, and does so within the time allowed, it may nevertheless be too late to alter their entitlement for that fortnight if the processing of their payment is already under way.

If pension payments are spread across the fortnight, the lead-up time to process each day's payment will be much shorter and advice of changes in circumstances is more likely to be taken into account in determining entitlement for the fortnight in question. We understand that this also provides savings to the government, but we are also supporting that aspect of the measure as being an improvement in the system generally.

Where the opposition differs from the government in terms of this bill is on the government's proposal to reduce the notification period for changes in circumstances by pensioner recipients from the current general 14-day provision to a provision of seven days. We are yet to be convinced of a rationale to support such a change to a shorter period. I know that during the committee inquiry into this bill the Department of Social Security argued that the old 14-day notification period had been based on the use of mail, and that the 14 days had been deemed originally to be reasonable to allow a transfer and processing of mail notification. I think now it is argued that, because of improved technology and the very much phone based system that is often used by Centrelink clients, a shorter period could be implemented.

We think, though, that there are real problems with a shorter notification period. I know that it does apply with a number of other pension payments. But we are most concerned that the shorter period may have a very deleterious effect on a number of recipients because, as senators would be aware, failure by a recipient to notify can result in them being in breach and, ultimately, they could be fined or have a loss of entitlement in serious cases. We do not see any justification at this stage in supporting a move to the shorter period. People on pensions do not have large financial reserves, and we think it is important that the system does not penalise them unfairly, does not cause them undue hardship because of what we think would be too short a period in which they have the right to notify of a change in circumstance.

We are particularly concerned at this time because of the context in which we are having this debate—the context of the ongoing problems with Centrelink. I think the government's case would be far more convincing if the Senate were assured that all pension recipients would have no difficulty in contacting Centrelink, that notifications were processed quickly and that the Centrelink organisation was responsive to their needs and their notification.

But, of course, the history of Centrelink in recent times is very different from that. The problems with Centrelink have been documented and very graphically characterised for us in the Ombudsman's report. We had the situation earlier this year where enormous phone delays were occurring, where people basically could not get through on the telephone to Centrelink to notify it of a change of circumstance. Centrelink encourages people to use the phone, to contact the organisation by that means rather than just fronting up to its office. In the July-August period this year, Centrelink had 900,000 calls of which it could only answer 90,000.

With Centrelink, you have an organisation struggling to cope with the demand of inquiries from recipients. The Ombudsman's report detailed the fact that, at various stages, Centrelink is only answering a third of the calls made to it. So we have an organisation that is struggling to answer two-thirds of the calls being made to it; and we have a government saying that we can have a shorter notification period. People are being required to notify Centrelink of changes to their circumstances within seven days rather than 14. The developments are clearly at odds.

If Centrelink were proving to be an organisation that was adequately resourced, that was coping well with the demands placed on it, then perhaps one could look at this measure differently. But, from the Labor opposition's point of view—with the history of Centrelink, the history of the underresourcing of that organisation, the very real issues people have in contacting Centrelink and getting service, in working through their problems of notifica tion and other queries—to reduce the notification period at this stage could be a very harsh measure and could unduly deprive people of entitlements through no fault of their own.

The Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation put their concerns to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee inquiry earlier this year. We know also that Centrelink has been struggling again more recently with the requirement to have `blockout days' where officers have not been taking appointments because they have been using those days to deal with the backlog of work.

We have had the recent announcement by the government that the efficiency dividend that they have applied to Centrelink will result in 5,000 more jobs going from Centrelink. Five thousand of the 24,000 jobs currently at Centrelink will be cut, therefore their potential to service their client base is reducing all the time.

The pressures on Centrelink are increasing as the government provides more and more work for that organisation to deal with. We just do not think they currently are coping adequately. This is not a criticism of the staff; it is just the reality that they have not got the resources allocated to meet the tasks set for them by government. We also have Centrelink trying to overcome this problem by an increasing reliance on technology, which of course is not always favoured by some of the client groups of Centrelink as they are often unfamiliar with or unhappy with dealing with that sort of technology.

So we have got a whole range of issues occurring inside Centrelink that go directly to their ability to service their client base. It just seems to us that, in that context, it is totally inappropriate to be saying to the client base, `You risk being breached, you risk having financial penalties put on you if you fail to notify us of a change of circumstances within seven days,' when the system is clearly incapable of servicing that client base and meeting that seven-day deadline in all circumstances. So, for those reasons in particular, we think the move from 14 to seven days is particularly inappropriate at this stage. We may well have taken that view anyway, but it certainly reinforces our view that now is not the time to reduce the notification period.

I notice also that this measure is due to commence on 1 July. July is not a terribly good time for Centrelink from what we have seen in the last year or so. I gather there are child-care funding changes also proposed for the start of the financial year. We just think that Centrelink will be under enormous pressure at that time of the year, and we suspect we might have problems similar to the disaster that was the introduction of the youth allowance last year, where so many clients of Centrelink could not get proper service.

Those contextual matters lead us to the position that we want to see the 14-day notification retained. I think the government has yet to make a convincing case for moving from the 14-day to the seven-day notification period anyway. In the absence of that case being put, I think we would have adopted a position of opposition to the reduction in notification, but in the current context I think it is even more important.

In conclusion, the opposition supports the bill because we recognise that running costs may indeed be reduced without harm to Centrelink clients by moving away from the overload of administration associated with pension Thursday. We support the rationalisation of payment cycles, but we are convinced that halving the notification period would cause hardship to clients, particularly given that the government has deprived Centrelink of the resources necessary to deliver income support fairly and efficiently within the current 14-day regime. In committee, we will seek the Senate's support to remove those provisions of the bill that would reduce the notification period from 14 to seven days.

talk.start.para: —The Payment Processing Legislation Amendment (Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements) Bill 1998 before us tonight will make a number of changes to the way in which social security payments are made. At the moment, some social security payments, such as Newstart, are calculated over a two-week period. That is, if a person is qualified for that payment for the whole of that two-week period, then they receive a full payment, but if they are only qualified for one of those weeks, they only receive half of the regular period payment. These types of payments are known as `period based payments'.

speech.para: While this system applies for some social security payments, other payments such as age pensions and family allowances are made under a different system altogether. Under that system, a person only needs to be qualified for their payment on one day in the fortnight to receive a full payment. For example, if a person's payment day is Thursday, it does not matter if that person qualified for the payment a fortnight ago or on the Tuesday two days prior, they still receive a full payment. Those types of payments are known as `payday based payments'.

This legislation we are debating at the moment is seeking to do away with these payday based payments and have all payments made under the period based system, using the rationale that it will simplify the system—something the Democrats always are keen to see—and introduce consistency into the way in which welfare payments are made. It will also more closely match the level of payments received with a person's period of eligibility. The Democrats are strongly in favour of any moves to simplify the social security system. We do not have any significant objections to the government's proposal. As such, we will be supporting schedule 1 of this bill.

This change will allow pensioners to receive their payment on a day of their choice, rather than having to receive it on a so-called pension Thursday. I do not know how many senators have been into their local bank on pension Thursday, but if they had they would realise that this is by far the busiest day of the fortnight for many bank branches. And that is not surprising when we see in the explanatory memorandum for this bill that there are around 2½ million pension payments made every second Thursday. I have no doubt that the banks would see a spreading of pension payment days as highly desirable. I am also sure that there will be a certain number of people who will welcome the opportunity to be able to choose, for whatever reason, to receive their pension on a different day.

Having said that, though, I think we do need to take note of the issues which were raised by the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation in their submission to the Community Affairs Legislation Committee inquiry. The APSF pointed out that in communities throughout Australia there can be a range of activities organised to coincide with pension Thursdays. For example, some local authorities provide community buses to collect older people from their homes and take them to the banks to collect their pension and then take them on to the shops and supermarkets to do their shopping. Also, some older persons' social groups base their activities around pension day. These are issues which can easily be overlooked in the development of a policy change like this one, but these are issues which are directly relevant to the way in which many older people live their lives.

As the APSF pointed out, these activities often provide avenues of friendship and social contact for isolated older people. Because of this, and because of other arrangements people may have made around their pension payday, I am sure a large number of people—at least for the first few years of their new arrangements—will continue to choose to receive their pension on the current pension Thursday. As such, the Democrats strongly support the call of the APSF that people should not be placed under any compulsion whatsoever now or in the future to move to a different pension payment day.

Whilst there may be administrative benefits for the government and the banks to have people's pension days spread evenly across the fortnight, the Democrats believe that the principle of choice that underlies this change must be retained across the board and people must be free to choose their day of payment, including retaining their existing one. At this stage, as far as I am aware, the government has not indicated any desire to require people to accept certain payment days, so I would simply put the Democrats' concern on the record for any future changes that might be considered.

Before moving on to other changes in this bill, I think it is appropriate to take the opportunity to highlight again the valuable role that the APSF played in the inquiry into this legislation, their submission to that inquiry and their continuing role as advocates for older people. The federation is surviving in the face of very harsh and, in the Democrats' view, unjustified cuts to their funding by this government. These cuts came about following the APSF's criticism of the government's aged care reforms. The APSF is now surviving primarily due to the great dedication of those who work for it. I would again put on the record the Democrats' very strong desire to see the government reconsider the APSF's funding situation because they clearly do play a very important role in providing advice and information to all political parties, including the government, about issues affecting older people.

Turning to schedule 3 of the bill, the primary change contained within this schedule is that it will reduce the period in which people must report changes in their circumstances to Centrelink from 14 days to just seven days. I note some circulated amendments to be moved on behalf of the government which appear to be reversing that situation to a large extent. I look forward to the parliamentary secretary's clarification of that. That seems like an improvement which goes a fair way to meeting the concerns that the Democrats expressed in our minority report to the community affairs committee and that Senator Evans outlined in his speech.

At the moment, if a person notifies Centrelink of changed circumstances which gives them an increased payment, they only receive that increase from the date of notification. Under this bill as it stands, Centrelink will backdate that increased payment to the date of the event which brought about the increase. That is actually quite positive, although if I read the government's amendments correctly that will be changed, but I will wait until the committee stage for the parliamentary secretary to clarify that.

The reduction in notification limits from 14 days to seven days has attracted criticism. The APSF, in addressing this part of the legislation, stated its opposition to this part of the legislation, as has the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney. The principal criticism is that it places too onerous a requirement on pensioners and families to notify Centrelink of their changed circumstances. This is particularly so given the ongoing difficulties people have in actually getting through to Centrelink on the phone.

I think it is worth raising this issue again, because it is such a fundamental one. I am sure any senators who have contact with members of the public who try to have dealings with Centrelink, which I imagine is just about all of us, will agree that it is one of the issues of greatest frustration, and one that, to be fair, has been an issue of frustration for such a long time, going back to the time when Labor was in office as well as when the coalition gained power. It has been an ongoing source of great irritation and annoyance to a huge number of people. It really is time something concrete and significant was done about it. Reducing staff is hardly the best way of addressing that.

I wish to read from a letter to the editor in the Sydney Morning Herald on 24 November from a Belinda Carson of Pymble, who wrote of her experience. She had been on the phone for 30 minutes trying to dial the Centrelink office. She had received a letter from Centrelink, asking her to get in touch within 14 days. She promptly reached for the phone to dial the number listed on the top of the page. She hit the redial button over and over within the space of half an hour. She could not even get through to be put on hold—just an engaged signal for half an hour. If that is the situation which is still facing people in Sydney, let alone in regional areas, just a couple of weeks ago, then clearly it is a problem that has not been addressed. Whilst that is the case, then it is clearly inappropriate to reduce any further the amount of time that people have to notify changes in their circumstances.

It is also worth highlighting the huge range of reasons that people have to give for changes in their circumstances. Whilst all of us in whatever role and responsibilities we have in life try to make sure we read all the fine print and all the details of every form that gets sent—forms can have a whole page of reasons why one needs to notify of a change in circumstances—it often takes people a little while to realise that they need to notify Centrelink about a particular change in their circumstances. If they run into the problem of not being able to get through, it is not surprising that often people have trouble meeting that deadline. I think it is a great myth to suggest that people on income support payments of whatever sort may have nothing better to do than to sit around all day and try to get through on the phone. Most of them live lives just as busy as any other people in the community.

Not long ago, following the introduction of the common youth allowance, we saw media reports of 90 per cent of calls to Centrelink not being answered. A proportion of these calls would obviously be repeat calls by the same person. Again, it is important to recognise some of the efforts Centrelink has taken to address this problem. But it does remain the case that it is very difficult for people to get through on the phone, and the telephone is the most commonly used means of informing Centrelink of changed circumstances. It is also worth noting the recent report of the Ombudsman in which the Ombudsman said:

At certain times of the day Centrelink's teleservice centres cannot cope with the level of inquiries. At peak times, even though the teleservice centres have a call queuing system, the caller gets a busy signal because the queues are already full.

So there are ongoing problems with the teleservice centres. The Democrats have grave reservations about the prospects of those problems being rectified in light of the many thousands of jobs that Centrelink is planning to shed over the next few years. Even putting those significant telephone contact problems to one side, the Democrats still believe that seven days may not be a sufficient period in which to require pensioners and families to contact Centrelink.

It is probably worth reminding the Senate that this chamber, including I believe the government senators, accepted that seven days was insufficient time for notification when we debated the common youth allowance legislation last year. Originally a seven-day notification period was proposed for that payment, but the Senate supported an amendment moved by my colleague Senator Stott Despoja to increase that to 14 days. As we heard via Senator Stott Despoja in question time in this place last week, there are huge problems even under that system in terms of the number of young people that will potentially have their payments cut off due to not getting forms back in in the appropriate length of time.

The only other comment I would make on this schedule is that, while the government wants to force people to inform Centrelink of any changes within one week, Centrelink has a full six weeks before it needs to act on that information. As a result of a government amendment some time back, Centrelink can take up to six weeks to act, safe in the knowledge that any overpayments it might make can be recovered as a debt. This applies where people have acted in good faith and have met the requirements for notifying Centrelink. Some of these overpayments are then able to be portrayed as fraud and used as justification for a further reduction in social security support.

That is an unfortunate side effect of some of the public campaigns that have been run on the quite justifiable government attempts to ensure people are receiving their accurate and appropriate payments. That is not something the Democrats have a problem with, but we do have a problem with some of the public interpretation of the information that comes out of those data-matching exercises. In this day of so-called reciprocal obligations the onus to act on new information seems to fall only on individuals, with no corresponding onus—or a much reduced onus—being placed on the department to act quickly on that information. As with many other measures in this area often dressed up under that reciprocal obligation tag, it seems fairly close to being a one-way street.

Just briefly, I would signal that during the committee stage of the debate on this bill I will be taking the opportunity to again request the Senate to reconsider the continuing operation of the two-year wait for newly arrived migrants in relation to the special benefit. I will go into that in not too much detail during the committee stage.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Evans and Senator Bartlett for their contributions. The Payment Processing Legislation Amendment (Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements) Bill 1998 contains two major provisions: proposals to move all social security and veterans' affairs payments to an arrears basis so that people receive their exact entitlement, and proposals to amend the date of effect provisions to give a seven-day notification period for changes in payments, events, et cetera. I have noted the comments that honourable senators have made, and the Minister for Family and Community Services was aware of the comments in the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee report. The government will be agreeing to accept the 14-day notification period but without beneficial backdating. We can discuss that further as we get into the committee stage.

speech.para: The payment in arrears proposals will correct present problems which result in some customers receiving too much and others receiving nothing at all. Customers will be paid for each and every day to which they are entitled—no more and no less. Currently, for example, a person who turns 65 the day before a pension payday gets a full pension payment, yet a person who turns 65 the day after the payday has to wait a full fortnight to receive payment.

On the date of effect provisions, customers will generally have a standard seven-day period to notify of changes in circumstances for the first time. Customers entitled to increases in their rate because of a change will be able to receive arrears, provided they notify Centrelink within the 14-day period when we have the amendments, seven-day period under the bill as it stands. Currently, increases only apply from the date of notification.

I want to reply to Senator Bartlett's comment about the difficulties of people contacting Centrelink. Whenever one has a telephone service, there will always be periods of peak pressure on those services. I have been advised that it is easier to get through in the more off-peak times. If we move to the 14-day notification, it gives people greater opportunity if they cannot get through in a peak period. There are also other methods of notifying the department, through mail or by dropping in the form.

Senator Bartlett highlighted the issue of pension day in particular for older pensioners. I say, `Halleluja, this bill is going through.' During the consultations for the International Year of Older Persons, one of the issues that came up over and over again was that older people saw themselves as being discriminated against and as being stigmatised. One of the very things that stigmatises people on age pensions is having to line up at the bank on pension day. Many people have a negative attitude that the banks are busy because pensioners are there on pension day. It also makes pensioners softer and easier targets for muggers, for people who know that pensioners are more likely to go to the bank on that day.

When we were doing the consultations, an older gentleman from one of the Victorian regional areas said to me, `What I would like to see you do is to stop them putting up petrol prices in regional areas on pension day.' I said, `Hopefully we are going to fix that with the new legislation because pension day will gradually disappear. There won't be a day on which prices can be put up.' So this is great news for older people in particular because it will relieve the strain. It will give them some opportunity to be paid on a day which is more suitable to them.

This is a great initiative that Senator Newman has put in place. She had to think about it some time ago for the legislation to get to this point. She saw it as one of the initiatives that social security could put in place for the International Year of Older Persons.

It is one way in which we can demonstrate our care for older people in particular, although it does benefit all other recipients of social security benefits and payments. I commend the bill to the Senate. I believe that the measures in it are innovative and have a number of foreseen positive benefits that the minister has outlined previously. I think she will be telling us much more about these benefits because this is a very good news story, particularly for older people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of this bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

talk.start.para: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. This memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 7 December 1998. I seek leave to move the government amendments that have been circulated in the chamber.

—First of all, I want to know whether the government are trying to move those amendments as one set. I thought the government needed to seek leave and I was going to deny them leave unless the parliamentary secretary provided an explanation.
—I apologise but—

—Perhaps the parliamentary secretary could wait just a second. I have only just seen these amendments to be moved on behalf of the government, so I have a range of questions I want to ask about them. It would probably be useful if the parliamentary secretary started by explaining why the government sought to change its position. I do not know about Senator Bartlett but I would certainly be interested, as I am sure other senators listening to the debate in their offices would be. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary could take us through that and that would save us time down the track.

speech.para: While she is doing that, I would appreciate an explanation of the financial impact statement contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum because I am not quite sure what that is supposed to mean. If she could take us through that too, that would be helpful.

talk.start.para: —This is challenging me, since the minister was going to take the bill through this stage but cannot do so due to unforeseen circumstances. I have had a brief briefing, but I did not look at the running sheet before I sought to move those amendments.

speech.para: Most of those amendments that you see there relate to substituting 14 days for seven days, as I indicated in the second reading speech. The government agrees with the sentiments of the chamber and the sentiments of the two senators who spoke—Senator Evans and Senator Bartlett, on behalf of the opposition and the Democrats—that it would be a more feasible, workable and acceptable process if we had a 14-day reporting period. Although it seems like there are a lot of amendments, they basically substitute 14 days for seven days in the various schedules.

talk.start.para: —I think you will find they do more than that.
—If I could just clarify the situation: the matter is that leave must be granted.

—If the parliamentary secretary got a further briefing, I think she would realise that her amendments do more than that. There are two separate issues contained in her amendments. It would be my intention that we deal with them separately, not as a whole. I was more interested in her explanation for the second part, and I am not sure whether she has had a briefing on that yet. That goes to the nub of the issue.
—I think I indicated in my second reading speech that we weren't going to accept beneficial backdating but we would accept substituting 14 days for seven.

—I just thought it would be interesting to know why. You proposed it in your bill originally. You then produced amendments which were circulated in the chamber today seeking not to proceed with that matter and change the act. I think the Senate is entitled to an explanation.
—Senator Bartlett, do you have any question you wish to ask before Senator Patterson responds to Senator Evans?

—In terms of contrasting the government's amendments with the opposition's amendments, I understand that the government's amendments are basically doing the same thing as the opposition's except for the beneficial backdating. Is that correct?

—The answer to Senator Bartlett is that that is correct. The reason we are accepting the 14 days without beneficial backdating is that we are moving from seven days to 14 days. Beneficial backdating is not, nor has it ever been, a part of the social security system and it should not become so now. The government was prepared to accept beneficial backdating in the context of seven-day notification because it was a shorter period of time. However, given the Senate's reluctance to adopt a seven-day notification period, we have compromised by offering a 14-day notification period. This is, after all, what we currently expect of age pensioners—that is the system as it exists for age pensioners—and we cannot see any reason why other customers should not be treated in the same way and be expected to meet this basic requirement, given that we are agreeing to a 14-day notification period.

—I want to briefly respond to that by saying that the parliamentary secretary is not actually agreeing to a 14-day period. That is what currently exists in the act and the impact of the amendments are to take us back, as I understand it, largely to the status quo, but I am happy to be corrected if that is not right. My understanding is that, in the majority of cases, the 14-day period already applies.

speech.para: The government had convinced us on this beneficial backdating question. We had been swayed by the force of their arguments and had agreed to support that measure, so we are a bit surprised that the government do not wish to proceed with it. In that event, it seems to me that the government amendments would be best considered in two groups rather than in one. I understand what they are trying to do, but I think we need to have a vote on the measures separately. The government can seek leave to move those amendments together—and I am not sure why they are listed first on the running sheet—but I would have thought, and it may not be my place to say this, that as there are two groups of amendments that go to two separate issues they ought to be voted on separately.

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans mentioned a notification period for the payments of 14 days. In fact, a number of payments do not currently have a notification period of 14 days: Newstart allowance, mature age allowance, sickness allowance, special benefit and partner allowance. I am advised that they currently have a seven-day notification period.
—I was referring to this bill.

—Senator Evans keeps shouting out that they are not in this bill. The issue is that we have a range of notification periods. One of the reasons we are making the notification periods all the same is that there is one that is 21 days, some that are 14 days and some that are seven days. Throughout social security and social security benefits they have grown like Topsy. There has been no uniformity. One of the problems when you do not have uniformity is that individuals, especially if they are moving from one benefit to another, are not as aware of the rules and are more likely to be in receipt of an overpayment through an error because they thought they had 14 days and it was seven days, or they thought they had 21 days and it was 14 days or whatever. This will make them all the same. Also, it is more likely that staff at Centrelink will be able to give them the correct advice because there is one notification period for all payments.

speech.para: The reason for trying to bring them together and make them the same was to make the rules about social security much more transparent and much less likely to be subjected to errors, either on the part of the recipient or on the part of the people advising them.
