I would appreciate your expert advice on that before declaring that with any great certainty because I want to be sure that I have not dudded myself and I want you to share the responsibility for that decision, Mr Temporary Chairman!
—Senator Evans, we have backtracked slightly through the maze and we think you are correct. Senator Patterson, do you want to add something?

—I had hoped that you were calling on the Temporary Chairman's expert advice, Senator Evans, because I agree that those are now redundant and all we have left to deal with is Senator Bartlett's amendment.
—We will proceed with Senator Bartlett's amendment while we figure out what the state of the opposition amendment is.
—I move Democrats amendment No. 1 on sheet 1179:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(1) Page 156 (after line 30), after Schedule 3, insert:

para.inline: Schedule 3A—Newly arrived resident's waiting period for special benefit

speech.para: 1 Subsection 23(1) (paragraph (g) of the definition of newly arrived resident's waiting period )
Repeal the paragraph.
2 Subsection 23(1) (paragraph (ka) of the definition of waiting period )
Repeal the paragraph.
Repeal the paragraph.
Repeal the sections.

This amendment relates to the newly arrived resident's waiting period for special benefit. I do not want to go into this in great detail, although I feel four minutes probably is not adequate to deal with it—15 minutes maybe—in which case we probably will not get to a vote on it tonight.

Just briefly, it is a matter that has been dealt with by the Senate a couple of times before. Whilst I do not like making a habit of continually bringing back decisions for another vote when I do not like the decision, I think this is an issue which is one of great significance. It is clearly causing a lot of hardship out in the community and I think it is fair to say that the evidence of that hardship is such that it is becoming clearer over time that unintended consequences have come forward from this measure and they are still happening out there. So rather than traverse over the arguments that I have put forward many times before in this chamber, I would simply request that the Senate give this matter consideration again because I do believe it is important. It is not a very costly measure, but it will clearly alleviate a lot of hardship that is happening out in the community.

Since senators will probably have the chance to ponder this matter overnight, for those senators who wish to get a reasonably good snapshot of such hardship, I refer them to the very extensive article that was in the Sydney Morning Herald Good Weekend Magazine on 12 September 1998 by David Lazar. This article outlined in great detail the impact of this measure on a number of families. The simple measure that we can adopt now to remove that hardship is to support my amendment.

Senator Harradine has suggested that it may be beneficial for me to read a couple of examples. I do urge senators to read through this article. Basically it gives examples of a number of families who have migrated to Australia—who have basically been invited into this country to be productive citizens—including skilled migrants as well as people coming here under sponsored migration. Circumstances for these families have not, for a variety of reasons, panned out the way they suspected, and the article gives quite clear examples of absolute extreme hardships—children suffering malnutrition and parents suffering psychiatric breakdown and becoming potentially suicidal.

I am sure that was not the intention of this measure when it was introduced. This amendment is not going to cost a great deal in terms of budgetary implications and it is going to save a great deal in the long term in terms of social damage as well as the economic impact of trying to pick up the pieces after this sort of hardship happens. I would urge the Senate, if they have not yet made up their minds, to ponder this overnight and to give consideration to supporting this amendment.

talk.start.para: —This is an extremely important amendment. It is one that I feel should, as Senator Bartlett mentioned, be considered in depth and thoroughly. I, together with Senator Bartlett, urge all honourable senators in this chamber and outside the chamber to have a look at this measure overnight. I do not suppose we will get to it until maybe 5 o'clock or half past four tomorrow afternoon, so I do urge honourable senators to have a look at this matter, to realise its importance and to consider voting for the measure.

speech.para: Progress reported.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title: Miriuwong and Gajerrong Decision

talk.start.para: —I want to spend the short 10 minutes that I have available to me tonight to give the Senate some warning of the recent decision made by the Federal Court judge Justice Malcolm Lee with respect to the Miriuwong and Gajerrong people of the East Kimberley. The decision that the judge made goes well beyond the Mabo decision made in 1992, and one would not have thought that that would have been possible with the devastation and the potential that that had for political and economic disruption to what was previously seen as always being a politically stable country.

speech.para: The decision made by Justice Malcolm Lee in effect gave 28 applicants over 7,000 square kilometres of land in a very potentially wealthy part—and, in fact, manifestly wealthy part—of the East Kimberley with respect to minerals and agriculture. It also included rights to fishing. Whilst the application was made by only 28 people, it encompassed no more than 200 people from both the Miriuwong and Gajerrong families. The area is larger than some countries in Europe. It is the first time that any judge in Australia has made such a decision in respect of the Australian mainland.

When the decision was made by the High Court of Australia to grant the Murray Island people, the Mer people, right and title and to recognise their native title to the islands just south of the coast of Papua New Guinea, it had few serious ramifications for Australian people. The extrapolation of what Justice Malcolm Lee has now done in Australia throws that into disarray. He has gone, as I said, far beyond what the High Court did with the Mabo and the more recent Wik decisions.

I guess it would be fair to say that, now that the land has been granted by the Federal Court, the Western Australian government has no option but to appeal that decision. It has no option because Justice Lee has said that the area encompassed in that in excess of 7,000 square kilometres includes mineral rights. The serious outcome of that for pastoralists is obvious. The serious outcome of that for miners is equally obvious. And there are serious outcomes for tourist operators and for everyone engaged in the agricultural industry there because it also includes vast amounts of the Fitzroy Valley, Lake Argyle, the Argyle Dam and areas that are of significance to the economy of Australia.

This opens the floodgate for similar applications to be made unless the insanity of Justice Lee's decision is overturned by either the full bench of the Federal Court or, ultimately, one would hope, the High Court of Australia. I live in hope that, when the High Court of Australia finds that the native title it said existed for the Mer people of the Murray Island could be extrapolated to the mainland of Australia—3,000 square miles of Australia; an area the same size as the United States of America—the High Court will in its wisdom find that the excesses of Justice Malcolm Lee cannot be allowed to be tolerated both for the political stability of Australia and for Western Australia.

This will not just stop in Western Australia, of course. Let me cover the ramifications of this for Western Australia and the nation. Whilst Western Australia has 9.7 per cent of the population of Australia, nonetheless it produces 27½ per cent of national export income. If a claim were to cover other areas in Australia—and anyone could claim it; 28 people claimed 7,000 square kilometres—what a catastrophe. The claim of those 28 people, unwittingly or wittingly through their legal advisers, now encompasses an area of land that could inhibit the development and the wealth of Australia.

Western Australia produces the greatest amount of oil condensate and gas in the nation. It is the biggest producer and exporter of alumina powder in the world. It is the biggest producer of diamonds in the world, mining over 40 million carats last year from the Argyle diamond mine, which is encompassed by this grant. It is also the biggest producer of gold by far in the nation. It is the third biggest producer of gold in the world, mining over a record $5 billion of gold last fiscal year. It is the biggest producer of iron ore in the world. It is the biggest producer of wheat in the nation—not that too much is grown in the Kimberley, but the extrapolation of that must go to other areas of Western Australia and other areas of Australia if this is allowed to pass.

It is the first time, as I said, that this sort of native title claim has been successfully granted by a superior court in Australia. The decision contradicts the Howard 10-point plan, that plan that we reassured the mining industry, the pastoral industry and the rural industries of Australia would be amended so that there would be not just certainty with respect to the production that makes Australia such a wealthy place to live in and the envy of the world but certainty of title for people engaged in those industries. Once again it creates uncertainty both for those industries I have mentioned and for the titles. It leaves a potential liability of $1.3 billion if the state government successfully overturns that; it is liable for the payment to 28 applicants—possibly up to 200—of $1.3 billion.

The justice gave no reason for some of the things that he did. Why did he do this when the High Court clearly gave a judgment that we thought was harsh, that we, as the engine room of Australia in Western Australia, thought was a harsh judgment against Western Australia? Why did Justice Lee do this? I cannot answer that. But I can say that, unless the full bench of the Federal Court or ultimately the last appellate court in Australia overturns that decision, you will have a few people controlling and owning Australia—not necessarily Aboriginal people but people who choose to call themselves Aboriginal people.

We have an island continent with no frontiers and we are creating frontiers. You have to get a permit to enter places. The middle of Western Australia, part of the Northern Territory and the north-west corner of South Australia is an area larger than France that Aboriginal people already have. Aboriginal people have 50 sheep stations and cattle stations in Western Australia that already amount to 25 million acres of land. Is it that we should live in a fraction of the land and that a few people who decide to call themselves Aboriginal or are Aboriginal should live in the vast bulk of it? It is a formula that is bound to fail. It is a formula that is going to create much more dissension between people who choose to say they are black Australians or those of us who choose to call ourselves white Australians or from Asia or anywhere else, bar being an Aboriginal person. It will create dissent.

Native title cannot be partly extinguished. It can either be extinguished or native title exists. Justice Lee makes no mention of how coexistence works there. He makes no mention of how much minerals should be given to Aboriginal claimants over the area. He makes no mention of access. But he does say that, if Aboriginal people want to keep out other people, they are quite entitled to do that. This has set a precedent in Australia. In an island nation with no frontiers we are creating frontiers for ourselves. Whether you want to call that a permit to enter or a visa to enter, as they do in Europe or other parts of the world, it makes no difference. We have created a situation where visas will be needed to enter Aboriginal land.

Future generations will not thank us for what we have done. They will not thank Justice Lee for what he has done. The time has come for us to legislate away native title with fairness. If that cannot be done, it is time for us to seriously consider a referendum to control native title once and for all. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On Friday and Saturday last week here in Parliament House, hundreds of delegates assembled for the inaugural National Children's Summit. The Coalition for Australia's Children, which is represented by over 50 organisations—including AYPAC, Centacare, Kids Helpline and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, just to name a few—brought together in a wonderful forum thoughts and ideas of many young people and advocates of youth and children.

speech.para: Thomas Keneally, one of the people present, gained a rapport with the gathered crowd with his comments about the role of education for young people. It found resonance in the packed forum, and many other advocates of children and youth were there to discuss the frameworks for the future and corporate and community partnerships.

The conference culminated in a declaration and plan for action, and the conference was structured in such a way that the young people present had the final say, a right of veto, if you like, on the outcome. An active program to empower the young people at the conference paid off, in my view, with youth delegates coming away knowing they had achieved something very important for their efforts.

His Excellency the Governor-General opened the conference with a heart-warming address following a traditional welcome by the Ngunnawal people. But one of the things that impressed me most about the structure of the conference was the way that both youth and children's issues were brought together in a holistic representation of the challenges that were confronting the next generation in Australia. So often we see youth issues metamorphose over time into narrow policy channels that actually militate against progression and lateral approaches to solving very complex and persistent social and economic problems.

It was very clear at the opening session that this summit grew out of a sense of frustration, a sense of futility, that was felt by many under the federal government, particularly with respect to, I think, the lack of leadership of John Howard. In my view, there has been a failure on behalf of the coalition government to provide even a sense of leadership for younger generations of Australians. Our young people are such a source of inspiration yet, every time there is a cut to education, a slash to support for students, the government is saying, `We do not value you and we do not value your contribution to society. You know this because we do not invest in you.' This is the message of the coalition. Is it any wonder that the self-esteem of so many young people is flattened? Whilst the spirit of the summit was soaring, John Howard's lack of attendance—

talk.start.para: —Mr Howard, please.

—Sorry, Mr Howard. Mr Howard's lack of attendance offended many delegates, particularly many young people. It was known at the conference that he was in the building at the time but could not find the time to make an appearance, let alone find the time to listen. This was the message I received from so many young people: it was one thing to be able to express your point of view, it was another to have those in positions of power, in positions to actually make decisions, listen to and act upon the words they heard.

speech.para: The last 2½ years have seen so many community services affecting quality of support to our young people diminished. There are several specific changes including the changes to Youth Allowance, which effectively threw 13,000 unemployment benefit recipients into crisis when their support was cut. Over 33,000 had their benefits reduced. For children under five, the cuts to child care invariably impacted upon their places of care, although I have to say that it is a credit to the resilience and dedication of many child-care workers that there has been minimal impact on the quality of care. These cuts have tended to manifest themselves in a large number of centres closing their doors.

The Youth Round Table is another expression, I believe, of a failure of the coalition government to address youth policy adequately. The defunding of several representative organisations and the replacement of those organisations which evolved over time in response to community needs with the Youth Round Table that is yet to find its place and have its representation announced is an indictment of the lack of confidence the coalition has in actually being able to work with those who select themselves to advocate for and represent young people in Australia.

Bigger issues such as youth employment prospects for the future have been affected by the lack of industry policy in critical growth areas. One I am particularly interested in, information technology, is a terrific example. The lack of industry policy there is a great indictment of the government as young people have shown themselves to be global leaders in creative innovation, with people like Alex Hartman inspiring new generations of entrepreneurs.

A glimpse at the IT pages in any of the newspapers shows it is young people pushing the outer boundaries of cultural expression through new media such as the World Wide Web. It was pleasing to note that the conference made a terrific effort to have a presence on the Internet, to which they are posting the outcomes of the conference and several of the key discussion points.

On this point, portrayal of young people in the media proved to be an interesting discussion. Not all media have the same positive view of young people as Internet pages. There was an acknowledgment that there really needed to be a generational shift in attitudes to the culture and life choices of Australia's youth, but this shift would probably not come with those in power actually changing their minds and doing things differently. Those in power have to move over and give space to new thought.

I want to congratulate the participants in the conference and assure them that there were members of political parties present, with me, Wayne Swan and Tanya Plibersek representing the Labor Party, listening to the issues raised and taking their deliberations away from that conference to form part of our policy considerations in the future.

There were many issues traversed, and the major outcomes of the conference included that the National Children's Summit recognise that it is a fundamental right of all children and young people to be heard and to live their life with dignity and respect; recognise the vulnerability of childhood and the fact that many children and young people face serious problems that push them to the margins of society and inhibit their full participation; reconcile and acknowledge the diversity of Australia's children and young people; and call on all Australian governments and the wider community to endorse this declaration and commit themselves to a plan of action.

I have not been able to do justice to the wide range of issues that were traversed at the summit. Rather than take up further time, I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard the declaration produced by the National Children's Summit of Australia 1998.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

para.inline: Our vision for children and young people

speech.para: Children and young people are entitled to full and active participation in Australian society.

The first National Children's Summit affirms that the well being of our children and young people is central to the achievement of a fair and decent society. We commit ourselves to an Australia where our young people are supported to be healthy, contributing, responsible, and confident citizens.
The National Children s Summit
. Recognises it is a fundamental right, of all children and young people to be heard and to live their life with dignity and respect.
. Recognises the vulnerability of childhood and the fact that many children and young people face serious problems that push them to the margins of society and inhibits their full participation.
. Reconcile and acknowledges the diversity of Australia's children and young people.
. Call on all Australian Governments and the wider community to endorse this Declaration and commit themselves to a Plan of Action.

The National Children's Summit confirms the importance of Australia's obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, signed in 1990 with the joint support of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. We celebrate the sensible and achievable provisions of the Convention. In 1998 the Convention was again endorsed by the Joint Treaties Committee of the Federal Parliament.

The National Children's Summit has prepared a draft Plan of Action for Children and Young People in Australia. This document contains a commitment by governments, corporations, community organisations, institutions, families and individuals to work together for the dignity and well being of all Australian children and young people.

para.inline: Our Responsibilities for children and young people

speech.para: We all have the responsibility to ensure that the best interests of children and young people are reflected in decisions and actions affecting them. We must eliminate the barriers that inhibit young people's participation in society.

Governments have a particular responsibility with children and young people with respect to the provision, planning and review of things such as education, health care, social security, alternative care, and juvenile justice, and other issues. They must ensure the co-ordinated development and delivery of services, supported by the resource allocations that reflects the needs of children and young people. They must also support the parents and carers in their efforts to provide children and young people with an adequate standard of living and the care they need.

Businesses should strive for a culture of corporate citizenship that takes full account of the best interests of children and young people. This includes a range of flexible work practices to support children and families. Children must be treated fairly as consumers and an ethical approach to marketing and advertising is especially important.

Community organisations should give priority to working in genuine partnership with children and young people. This includes developing practices that encourage and enable children and young people to actively participate in organisational decision making. It also means supporting children and young people to establish their own organisations and approaches.

para.inline: Our commitments to children and young people

speech.para: The Summit has made a number of commitments to the children and young people of Australia. Those commitments are based on:
Partnership

All sections of the community must work together in genuine partnership for the benefit of children and young people. Governments, businesses, community groups and the young people themselves all have unique yet complimentary contributions to make. The commitment to partnership and participation of children and young people should form the basis to all of the other commitments in the Plan of Action.
Policy

A comprehensive national policy framework for children and young people should be developed through a process of co-operation between all Australian governments and other sectors, including young people themselves.
Consultation and Feedback
Government and other sectors should undertake regular and genuine consultation and feedback outcomes of that consultation with young people when developing policies and programs.
Advocacy
Children and young people are entitled to a strong advocacy of their rights and interests. This includes peer advocacy and the support for it. Without this, some voices will continue to go unheard.
Resources
Children and young people are entitled to a fair and equitable share of the nation's resources. Their status as citizens in our society demands nothing less.
Research
To enhance our knowledge and understanding of children and young people, comprehensive and up-to-date research on issues affecting their lives is essential.
We are determined to carry forward the commitments we have made to the children and young people of this nation.
We call on all Australians to work with us in achieving the vision of a society that truly respects and values its children and young people.

We invite the leaders of government, businesses, community organisations and young people themselves to meet again with in three years to review progress of the Plan of Action, update the commitments and take other action as necessary to ensure that all children and young people receive a fair share in the life of this nation.

talk.start.para: —On that note, I conclude by saying that there is a desperate need to take a broader view of youth issues confronting our future generations. Many of the paths trodden so far by the coalition do not head in the right direction. I am hopeful, as a result of this conference, that the government will take some heart and some guidance and leadership from those who were prepared in their own time to come together in this place over the past few days and put their thoughts and feelings on the public record.

—I rise briefly tonight to address an issue relating to one of the concerns I raised in my first speech in this place, which is the need to raise public awareness about some of the conditions and suffering experienced by animals in our community. Some senators may have read an article in the Sydney Morning Herald last week on 1 December by Ben Power which highlighted the death of one of two female elephants—Ranee, a 43-year-old elephant, who died on Sunday last week.

speech.para: That is a sad thing, but I guess of its own it does not raise any animal welfare concerns. An issue which was highlighted in the article, as the zoo's general manager of life sciences, Mr William Meikle, explained, is that in the wild female elephants live together and form very strong bonds with each other. This elephant which died, Ranee, and the zoo's other female elephant, Burma, a 41-year-old elephant, had been together for 16 years.

As is clearly highlighted in the article, the surviving companion experienced—and is presumably still experiencing—a great deal of grief at the death of its companion. The article indicated that no replacement female would be sought in the short term, but next March the female elephant and the zoo's male elephant will be relocated to the Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo while a new elephant exhibit is being built at Taronga. I presume those elephants will be able to exist and have companions with other animals there.

The difficulties that zoos face in keeping large animals and adequately addressing animal welfare concerns was addressed in an article by Sian Powell in the Australian last Friday which highlighted the virtual impossibility of keeping mega fauna in adequate space in a city style zoo. This applies to elephants, lions, tigers and the like. For those who saw the very insightful ABC series into zoos some time back, it was very clear that, whilst those caring for elephants do as much as is humanly possible to address the needs of the large animals, clearly in that circumstance it is not feasible to adequately address the behavioural needs of elephants. It is not surprising that zoos have difficulty in meeting some of these requirements. They have the competing demands of needing to entertain the public along with education and the increasing focus that many zoos are placing on conservation areas.

I raise this by way of preliminary indication of the importance of ensuring that large animals are kept in adequate conditions. I also want to highlight the far worse situation that a solitary elephant is facing at the moment in a circus in New South Wales, the Stardust Circus. This single female elephant has been alone since her lifelong companion died over two years ago. This is in clear contravention of the New South Wales government's own regulations under the Exhibited Animals Protection Act of New South Wales.

A report was done by animal behavioural scientist Dr Roger Mugford, who visited the Stardust Circus at the start of November in Canterbury in Sydney. He inspected the circus for about an hour, and he identified a large number of potential problems. A major problem which I have mentioned and which is highly significant is that of a single elephant basically being kept in solitary for over two years, which is in clear contravention of the act. There are a number of other problems with the actual conditions in which the elephant is kept.

According to the preliminary report provided by Dr Mugford, the elephant, whose name is Arna, was not safely enclosed and is in constant, intimate and unsupervised contact with members of the public whilst being inadequately restrained by a single tape. I have seen video evidence of that. The elephant is unable to escape the attention of the public, which is another breach of the act. It has no access to overnight shelter which will protect the elephant from climatic extremes, which is another breach of the act. Inadequate shade is provided for the elephant. No supply of drinking water was witnessed for the elephant during the hour long inspection.

Dr Mugford identified damage to the elephant's ears on their outer edge by the harsh use of a training instrument. He stated that foot care to the elephant had been neglected, skin care of the elephant seemed to be non-existent, transportation of the elephant in the trailer parked at the circus would pose extreme danger and induce stress, and a circular balancing table of strong steel con struction was found to have a sharp jagged weld that would cause pain and possible injury to the elephant during circus performances.

All those conditions I have read out are clear breaches of the New South Wales Exhibited Animals Protection Act. I raise them tonight simply to highlight the lack of action there has been in this area. Often governments, whether at state or federal level, say, `We have regulations, we have codes of practice, we have guidelines to meet all these concerns, so don't worry about it,' which is all well and good. But the key issue is ensuring that those guidelines, regulations, laws, or whatever, are enforced. Clearly, this is a case where that is not happening.

Regardless of all the specific problems with the conditions that the elephant faces at that circus, the bottom line is that an elephant, particularly a female one, should not be kept in solitary confinement, as has been done in this case for two years. Also, there is a free range sanctuary in South Australia which is offering a home to this elephant. There obviously, firstly, she will have a lot more space and, secondly, she will be able to interact with others of her species—which is a condition that is clearly desirable and, again going back to the situation at the Taronga Park Zoo, one that most animal behaviourists and animal handlers at zoos, those who do make some effort to care for the needs of their animals, I am sure, would agree is a far more desirable outcome.

I call on the New South Wales government to ensure that its own regulations are enforced. We have a situation where this elephant has been in solitary for around two years, in contravention of the act, and with there being an alternative organisation that is willing to take the elephant—which might otherwise be a problem. Given that the solution to that problem is there, and with the clear breaches of the act that exist having been brought to the attention of the government, I simply join in the calls of many others throughout the country, and particularly throughout New South Wales, for the government to ensure that its own act is enforced and require the circus to surrender its elephant as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —On Saturday, 6 December 1998, His Excellency Richard O'Brien unveiled a monument erected on the foreshore of the Burgoyne Reserve, Williamstown, Victoria, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Great Hunger in his native Ireland. With pathos and eloquence, he told of that defining but horrific period in Irish history and of its impact on Australia. The monument is made up of basalt rock which was thrown up by a nearby volcano hundreds of thousands of years ago and metal inscriptions, which include the following words:

speech.para: In memory of one million people who died in Ireland during the Great Hunger of 1845-1852. In praise of the courage of tens of thousands of dispossessed Irish who sailed to Hobsons Bay to build a new life. In sorrow for the dispossession of the Bunurong and Woiworung people but in a spirit of reconciliation. In solidarity with all those who suffer hunger today.

The Bunurong people originally held the land upon which the monument is set, and Victor Briggs from that tribe welcomed those who gathered for the ceremony. So too did Councillor Brad Matheson, the present day Mayor of Hobsons Bay.

Peter Kiernan, of Irish descent but thoroughly Australian, responded to the ambassador's address. Francis O'Meara played a lament on the uillean pipes which evoked the mood of grief but also of hope which must have informed the air on the Williamstown foreshore 150 years ago. Loretta Brennan sang a song with pure voice, unaccompanied by any musical instrument. It spoke of the tragedy and courage of yesteryear that has now become part of the histories of Australia and of Ireland.

The monument is the outcome of the inspiration and work of the `Irish Famine Commemoration Committee—Melbourne', wonderfully led by Val Noone. Its other members are Loretta Brennan, Mary Doyle, Patricia Foley, Mary Kenneally, Peter Kiernan, Michael O'Grady, Paul Ormonde, Louis de Paor, Pauline Rule and Chris Watson. Pauline Rule, an historian, told the gathering why the day and place had been chosen for the ceremony. On 6 December 1848, 191 Irish orphan girls arrived in Hobsons Bay on the Lady Kennaway, a sailing ship of 585 tons. They came from a land in which the native population had been devastated to one from which the Bunurong and Woiworung people had but recently been ousted. They were typical of many Irish girls and young women who arrived in Australia without their families during the Great Famine. Many of us have them as forebears. They met hardship, prejudice, want and an alien environment with courage and, ultimately, with triumph. Their contribution to Australia has been immense.
In 1994 This Great Calamity, a history of the Irish famine 1845-52, written by Christine Kinealy, was published in Dublin. In it, she wrote:

At the end of the Famine, it was evident that substantial changes had taken place in the country. In the 1850s the Census Commissioners recorded that in the ten years from 1841 to 1851 the population had fallen from 8,175,124 persons to 6,552,385 persons. They also estimated that if the famine had not occurred, the population of Ireland in 1851 would have been 9,018,799.

The Great Hunger slaughtered a staggering number of people; it made migrants of even more. It was the occasion of many a Celt coming to Australia from Ireland. They were, in the most part, poor in resources, reduced in social standing, but rich in spirit. They and their descendants have done mighty things for Australia. In the 19th century, they set the model for migrants who have since followed them here from numerous countries around the world. Those with Irish antecedents who arrived here during the Great Hunger demonstrate how much Australia has gained from people who have come to it out of places where they were subject to oppression, privation and prejudice.
The Great Famine was a horror in history. It resonates in Ireland to this day. It has left its mark on Australia's story and on its char-
acter. Australia was the place where many of its victims found redemption; that is a process a host of migrants have experienced since then. We should never put that process at risk.
